composerInfo.name: Veda Vyasa
composerInfo.biography: Krishna Dvaipayana Vyasa, compiler of the Vedas, author of the Mahabharata and Puranas, and the son of Parashara and Satyavati.

chandas.name: Anushtup
chandas.description: The most common meter in Sanskrit literature, used in the Bhagavad Gita and most stotras.

metadata.historicalContext: From the Anushasana Parva (Chapter 149) of the Mahabharata. Revealed by Bhishma to Yudhishthira on the battlefield of Kurukshetra while lying on a bed of arrows.

disclaimer.text: The meanings and translations provided here are approximations meant to aid learning and devotion. Sanskrit, being a sacred and multi-layered language, carries depths of meaning that cannot be fully captured in English translation. Different acharyas and traditions may interpret verses differently based on their philosophical framework. For authoritative understanding and the complete essence of these sacred texts, please consult a qualified guru or traditional scholar in your sampradaya.
disclaimer.note: These interpretations draw from Shankaracharya's Advaita commentary, Parashara Bhattar's Vishishtadvaita commentary, and traditional Sanskrit grammar. The compound breakdowns (samasa vibhaga) follow traditional Sanskrit grammar but the spiritual significance goes far beyond linguistic analysis.

namaCountInfo.uniqueNamas: Varies by counting method (some names repeat)
namaCountInfo.note: Traditional count is 1000 names, though some commentators count differently based on how compound words are split.

lines.meaning: The Thousand Names of Lord Vishnu
lines.note: The Vishnu Sahasranama is a sacred hymn containing 1000 names of Lord Vishnu, found in the Anushasana Parva of the Mahabharata. It was revealed by the grandsire Bhishma to Yudhishthira while lying on a bed of arrows after the great war. This stotra is considered one of the most powerful and comprehensive hymns in Hindu tradition, encompassing the full glory of the Supreme Being.

lines.meaning: Om! (I meditate upon) the one clad in white garments, the all-pervading Vishnu, who is moon-complexioned and has four arms...

samasaVibhaga.combinedMeaning: One who wears white/pure garments
One whose complexion is like the moon (luminous, fair)
One who has four arms

lines.note: This is the Ganesha Dhyana Shloka, traditionally recited before beginning any sacred text. Though it describes Vishnu's form, it is addressed to Ganesha who removes all obstacles. The white garment and moon complexion describe the form of Mahaganapati.

lines.meaning: One should meditate upon Him with a serene, pleasant countenance for the complete pacification of all obstacles.

samasaVibhaga.combinedMeaning: One with a serene, pleasant face
For the complete removal of all obstacles

lines.note: This is the second half of the Ganesha Dhyana Shloka, traditionally recited before beginning any sacred text to invoke blessings for removing obstacles.

lines.meaning: He whose attendants, beginning with the elephant-faced one (Ganesha), number more than a hundred...

samasaVibhaga.combinedMeaning: Beginning with the elephant-faced one (Ganesha) and others
Attendants, members of the divine assembly

lines.note: This is the first half of the Vishvaksena Dhyana Shloka. Vishvaksena is the commander of Vishnu's army and is invoked before the Sahasranama.

lines.meaning: ...who constantly destroy all obstacles - I take refuge in that Vishvaksena.

etymology.dhatu: विष्वक् (viṣvak - in all directions) + सेना (sēnā - army)
etymology.meaning: One whose army extends in all directions; Commander-in-chief of Vishnu's divine forces

namaAnalysis.note: Vishvaksena is the general of Vishnu's divine army. In Vaishnava tradition, he is worshipped before any auspicious activity, similar to Ganesha in other traditions.

samasaVibhaga.combinedMeaning: One whose army extends in all directions

lines.meaning: Preliminary Introduction
lines.note: The Poorva Peetika (Preliminary Section) contains the invocations, the setting of the dialogue between Yudhishthira and Bhishma, and the six questions that Bhishma answers with the Sahasranama.

lines.meaning: (I salute) Vyasa, great-grandson of Vasishtha, grandson of Shakti, who is pure and sinless...

samasaVibhaga.combinedMeaning: Great-grandson of Sage Vasishtha
Pure, without any blemish or sin

lines.note: Vyasa's lineage: Vasishtha → Shakti → Parashara → Vyasa. This verse establishes the illustrious lineage of the compiler of the Mahabharata.

lines.meaning: ...I bow to the son of Parashara, the father of Shuka, who is a treasure-house of austerity.

samasaVibhaga.combinedMeaning: Son of Sage Parashara
Father of Sage Shuka
Treasury of austerity; one who has amassed great tapas

lines.note: Sage Shuka (Shukadeva) was Vyasa's illustrious son who narrated the Bhagavata Purana to King Parikshit.

lines.meaning: To Vyasa who is a form of Vishnu, and to Vishnu who has taken the form of Vyasa...

samasaVibhaga.combinedMeaning: To one who has the form of Vishnu
To one who has taken the form of Vyasa

lines.note: This verse establishes the identity of Vyasa with Vishnu. Vyasa is considered an avatara (incarnation) of Vishnu who descended to compile and divide the Vedas.

lines.deva: नमो वै ब्रह्मनिधये वासिष्ठाय नमो नमः ॥
lines.iast: namō vai brahmanidhayē vāsiṣṭhāya namō namaḥ ॥
lines.knda: ನಮೋ ವೈ ಬ್ರಹ್ಮನಿಧಯೇ ವಾಸಿಷ್ಠಾಯ ನಮೋ ನಮಃ ॥
lines.tel: నమో వై బ్రహ్మనిధయే వాసిష్ఠాయ నమో నమః ॥
lines.tam: நமோ வை ப்³ரஹ்மனித⁴யே வாஸிஷ்டா²ய நமோ நம: ॥
lines.guj: નમો વૈ બ્રહ્મનિધયે વાસિષ્ઠાય નમો નમઃ ॥
lines.pan: ਨਮੋ ਵੈ ਬ੍ਰਹ੍ਮਨਿਧਯੇ ਵਾਸਿਸ਼੍ਠਾਯ ਨਮੋ ਨਮਃ ॥
lines.mr: नमो वै ब्रह्मनिधये वासिष्ठाय नमो नमः ॥
lines.meaning: ...salutations to the treasure-house of Vedic knowledge (Brahman), to the descendant of Vasishtha, salutations again and again!

samasaVibhaga.combinedMeaning: To the treasury of Vedic/Brahman knowledge
To the descendant of the Vasishtha lineage

lines.meaning: To the unchanging One, the pure One, the eternal One, the Supreme Self...

etymology.meaning: Pure; untainted; free from all impurities

etymology.dhatu: नि (ni) + इ (i - to go) - that which always exists

etymology.meaning: The Supreme Self; the highest Soul

lines.meaning: ...to the One of eternally uniform form, to Vishnu, the all-conquering One!

etymology.dhatu: सदा (sadā - always) + एक (eka - one) + रूप (rūpa - form)
etymology.meaning: One whose form is eternally the same; unchanging in appearance
The all-pervading One; One who enters and permeates everything

etymology.dhatu: सर्व (sarva - all) + जि (ji - to conquer) + ष्णु (ṣṇu - suffix)

lines.meaning: By merely remembering whom, from the bondage of birth and worldly existence...

samasaVibhaga.combinedMeaning: By mere remembrance alone
From the bondage of birth and the cycle of worldly existence

lines.note: This is the famous verse proclaiming the power of simply remembering Vishnu's name - the foundation of Nama Japa.

lines.meaning: ...one is liberated - salutations to that Vishnu, the Lord of all beings!

etymology.meaning: The origin of all beings; the all-powerful Lord; the source of creation

samasaVibhaga.combinedMeaning: One is completely liberated/freed

lines.meaning: Om! Salutations to Vishnu, the origin and lord of all beings!
lines.note: This mantra is the essential invocation before beginning the Sahasranama. Om represents the primordial sound from which all creation emerges.

lines.meaning: Sri Vaishampayana said:
lines.note: Vaishampayana was a disciple of Vyasa who narrated the Mahabharata to King Janamejaya during the Sarpa Satra (snake sacrifice). This sets the narrative frame.

lines.deva: श्रुत्वा धर्मा नशेषेण पावनानि च सर्वशः ।
lines.iast: śrutvā dharmā naśēṣēṇa pāvanāni cha sarvaśaḥ ।
lines.knda: ಶ್ರುತ್ವಾ ಧರ್ಮಾ ನಶೇಷೇಣ ಪಾವನಾನಿ ಚ ಸರ್ವಶಃ ।
lines.tel: శ్రుత్వా ధర్మా నశేషేణ పావనాని చ సర్వశః ।
lines.tam: ஶ்ருத்வா த⁴ர்மா நஶேஷேண பாவனானி ச ஸர்வஶ: ।
lines.guj: શ્રુત્વા ધર્મા નશેષેણ પાવનાનિ ચ સર્વશઃ ।
lines.pan: ਸ਼੍ਰੁਤ੍ਵਾ ਧਰ੍ਮਾ ਨਸ਼ੇਸ਼ੇਣ ਪਾਵਨਾਨਿ ਚ ਸਰ੍ਵਸ਼ਃ ।
lines.mr: श्रुत्वा धर्मा नशेषेण पावनानि च सर्वशः ।
lines.meaning: Having heard all the dharmas completely, and all the purifying practices...

lines.ben: শ্রুত্বা ধর্মা নশেষেণ পাবনানি চ সর্বশঃ ।
lines.mal: ശ്രുത്വാ ധര്മാ നശേഷേണ പാവനാനി ച സർവശഃ ।
lines.meaning: ...Yudhishthira again addressed the son of Shantanu (Bhishma).

samasaVibhaga.combinedMeaning: Son of Shantanu (i.e., Bhishma)

lines.note: Bhishma, the great patriarch, lies on a bed of arrows after the Kurukshetra war, waiting for an auspicious moment to depart. Yudhishthira approaches him for final instructions.

lines.meaning: Yudhishthira said:
lines.note: Yudhishthira, the eldest Pandava known as Dharmaraja, poses six profound questions to Bhishma that form the basis of the entire Sahasranama.

lines.deva: किमेकं दैवतं लोके किं वाऽप्येकं परायणं
lines.iast: kimēkaṃ daivataṃ lōkē kiṃ vā'pyēkaṃ parāyaṇaṃ
lines.knda: ಕಿಮೇಕಂ ದೈವತಂ ಲೋಕೇ ಕಿಂ ವಾಽಪ್ಯೇಕಂ ಪರಾಯಣಂ
lines.tel: కిమేకం దైవతం లోకే కిం వాఽప్యేకం పరాయణం
lines.tam: கிமேகம் தை³வதம் லோகே கிம் வாப்யேகம் பராயணம்
lines.guj: કિમેકં દૈવતં લોકે કિં વાઽપ્યેકં પરાયણં
lines.pan: ਕਿਮੇਕਂ ਦੈਵਤਂ ਲੋਕੇ ਕਿਂ ਵਾ਽ਪ੍ਯੇਕਂ ਪਰਾਯਣਂ
lines.mr: किमेकं दैवतं लोके किं वाऽप्येकं परायणं
lines.meaning: Who is the One Supreme Deity in the world? Who is the One ultimate refuge?
lines.note: Questions 1 & 2: These are the first of six profound questions Yudhishthira asks Bhishma. They seek to identify the supreme object of worship and the ultimate goal of life.

lines.ben: কিমেকং দৈবতং লোকে কিং বাঽপ্য়েকং পরাযণং
lines.mal: കിമേകം ദൈവതം ലോകേ കിം വാഽപ്യേകം പരായണം
lines.meaning: By praising whom, by worshipping whom, can human beings attain auspiciousness (good fortune)?
lines.note: Questions 3 & 4: These questions ask about the practical means - through praise (stuti) and worship (archana) - by which humans can attain the highest good.

lines.deva: को धर्मः सर्वधर्माणां भवतः परमो मतः ।
lines.iast: kō dharmaḥ sarvadharmāṇāṃ bhavataḥ paramō mataḥ ।
lines.knda: ಕೋ ಧರ್ಮಃ ಸರ್ವಧರ್ಮಾಣಾಂ ಭವತಃ ಪರಮೋ ಮತಃ ।
lines.tel: కో ధర్మః సర్వధర్మాణాం భవతః పరమో మతః ।
lines.tam: கோ த⁴ர்ம: ஸர்வத⁴ர்மாணாம் ப⁴வத: பரமோ மத: ।
lines.guj: કો ધર્મઃ સર્વધર્માણાં ભવતઃ પરમો મતઃ ।
lines.pan: ਕੋ ਧਰ੍ਮਃ ਸਰ੍ਵਧਰ੍ਮਾਣਾਂ ਭਵਤਃ ਪਰਮੋ ਮਤਃ ।
lines.mr: को धर्मः सर्वधर्माणां भवतः परमो मतः ।
lines.meaning: Which dharma (righteous practice) is, in your opinion, the supreme among all dharmas?
lines.note: Question 5: This asks for the essence of all religious and moral duties - the one practice that encompasses all others.

lines.ben: কো ধর্মঃ সর্বধর্মাণাং ভবতঃ পরমো মতঃ ।
lines.mal: കോ ധര്മഃ സർവധര്മാണാം ഭവതഃ പരമോ മതഃ ।
lines.meaning: By chanting what (mantra/name) can a living being be freed from the bondage of birth and worldly existence?

samasaVibhaga.combinedMeaning: From the bondage of birth and the cycle of worldly existence (samsara)

lines.note: Question 6: The final and most crucial question - what is the supreme mantra or name that grants liberation (moksha)? Bhishma's answer to all six questions is the Vishnu Sahasranama.

lines.meaning: Shri Bhishma said
lines.note: This marks the beginning of Bhishma's answer to Yudhishthira's six questions. Bhishma, the grandsire of the Kuru dynasty, was a great devotee of Vishnu and possessed the boon of choosing his own time of death (ichcha mrityu). He delivers this sacred teaching while lying on his deathbed of arrows.

lines.meaning: The Lord of the universe, the God of gods, the Infinite One, the Supreme Being (Purushottama)...

samasaVibhaga.combinedMeaning: The Lord of the universe
God of gods (the supreme deity)
The Supreme Being, highest among all beings

lines.meaning: By praising with the thousand names, a person who is constantly uplifted (in devotion)...
lines.note: Bhishma begins his answer by describing the method and benefits of reciting the Sahasranama. The term 'satatotthita' indicates one who is ever alert and devoted.

lines.meaning: Worshipping Him alone daily with devotion, the Imperishable Being...
Meditating, praising, bowing, and worshipping Him alone...
Vishnu who is without beginning or end, the great Lord of all worlds...
By always praising the Lord of worlds, one transcends all sorrows.

lines.deva: ब्रह्मण्यं सर्व धर्मज्ञं लोकानां कीर्ति वर्धनम् ।
lines.iast: brahmaṇyaṃ sarva dharmajñaṃ lōkānāṃ kīrti vardhanam ।
lines.knda: ಬ್ರಹ್ಮಣ್ಯಂ ಸರ್ವ ಧರ್ಮಜ್ಞಂ ಲೋಕಾನಾಂ ಕೀರ್ತಿ ವರ್ಧನಮ್ ।
lines.tel: బ్రహ్మణ్యం సర్వ ధర్మజ్ఞం లోకానాం కీర్తి వర్ధనమ్ ।
lines.tam: ப்³ரஹ்மண்யம் ஸர்வ த⁴ர்மஜ்ஞம் லோகானாம் கீர்தி வர்த⁴னம் ।
lines.guj: બ્રહ્મણ્યં સર્વ ધર્મજ્ઞં લોકાનાં કીર્તિ વર્ધનમ્ ।
lines.pan: ਬ੍ਰਹ੍ਮਣ੍ਯਂ ਸਰ੍ਵ ਧਰ੍ਮਜ੍ਞਂ ਲੋਕਾਨਾਂ ਕੀਰ੍ਤਿ ਵਰ੍ਧਨਮ੍ ।
lines.mr: ब्रह्मण्यं सर्व धर्मज्ञं लोकानां कीर्ति वर्धनम् ।
lines.meaning: The supporter of Brahmins, knower of all dharma, enhancer of the glory of all beings...

lines.ben: ব্রহ্মণ্য়ং সর্ব ধর্মজ্ঞং লোকানাং কীর্তি বর্ধনম্ ।
lines.mal: ബ്രഹ്മണ്യം സർവ ധര്മജ്ഞം ലോകാനാം കീര്തി വര്ധനമ് ।
lines.meaning: The Lord of worlds, the Great Being, the source and origin of all creatures.

lines.deva: एष मे सर्व धर्माणां धर्मोऽधिक तमोमतः ।
lines.iast: ēṣa mē sarva dharmāṇāṃ dharmō'dhika tamōmataḥ ।
lines.knda: ಏಷ ಮೇ ಸರ್ವ ಧರ್ಮಾಣಾಂ ಧರ್ಮೋಽಧಿಕ ತಮೋಮತಃ ।
lines.tel: ఏష మే సర్వ ధర్మాణాం ధర్మోఽధిక తమోమతః ।
lines.tam: ஏஷ மே ஸர்வ த⁴ர்மாணாம் த⁴ர்மோதி⁴க தமோமத: ।
lines.guj: એષ મે સર્વ ધર્માણાં ધર્મોઽધિક તમોમતઃ ।
lines.pan: ਏਸ਼ ਮੇ ਸਰ੍ਵ ਧਰ੍ਮਾਣਾਂ ਧਰ੍ਮੋ਽ਧਿਕ ਤਮੋਮਤਃ ।
lines.mr: एष मे सर्व धर्माणां धर्मोऽधिक तमोमतः ।
lines.meaning: This, in my opinion, is the highest dharma of all dharmas...

lines.ben: এষ মে সর্ব ধর্মাণাং ধর্মোঽধিক তমোমতঃ ।
lines.mal: ഏഷ മേ സർവ ധര്മാണാം ധര്മോഽധിക തമോമതഃ ।
lines.meaning: That a person who always worships the lotus-eyed One (Pundarikaksha) with devotion and hymns...

lines.deva: परमं यो महत्तेजः परमं यो महत्तपः ।
lines.iast: paramaṃ yō mahattējaḥ paramaṃ yō mahattapaḥ ।
lines.knda: ಪರಮಂ ಯೋ ಮಹತ್ತೇಜಃ ಪರಮಂ ಯೋ ಮಹತ್ತಪಃ ।
lines.tel: పరమం యో మహత్తేజః పరమం యో మహత్తపః ।
lines.tam: பரமம் யோ மஹத்தேஜ: பரமம் யோ மஹத்தப: ।
lines.guj: પરમં યો મહત્તેજઃ પરમં યો મહત્તપઃ ।
lines.pan: ਪਰਮਂ ਯੋ ਮਹਤ੍ਤੇਜਃ ਪਰਮਂ ਯੋ ਮਹਤ੍ਤਪਃ ।
lines.mr: परमं यो महत्तेजः परमं यो महत्तपः ।
lines.meaning: He who is the supreme radiance, the supreme austerity...

lines.deva: परमं यो महद्ब्रह्म परमं यः परायणम् ।
lines.iast: paramaṃ yō mahadbrahma paramaṃ yaḥ parāyaṇam ।
lines.knda: ಪರಮಂ ಯೋ ಮಹದ್ಬ್ರಹ್ಮ ಪರಮಂ ಯಃ ಪರಾಯಣಮ್ ।
lines.tel: పరమం యో మహద్బ్రహ్మ పరమం యః పరాయణమ్ ।
lines.tam: பரமம் யோ மஹத்³ப்³ரஹ்ம பரமம் ய: பராயணம் ।
lines.guj: પરમં યો મહદ્બ્રહ્મ પરમં યઃ પરાયણમ્ ।
lines.pan: ਪਰਮਂ ਯੋ ਮਹਦ੍ਬ੍ਰਹ੍ਮ ਪਰਮਂ ਯਃ ਪਰਾਯਣਮ੍ ।
lines.mr: परमं यो महद्ब्रह्म परमं यः परायणम् ।
lines.ben: পরমং যো মহত্তেজঃ পরমং যো মহত্তপঃ ।
lines.mal: പരമം യോ മഹത്തേജഃ പരമം യോ മഹത്തപഃ ।
lines.meaning: He who is the Supreme Brahman, the ultimate refuge...

lines.deva: पवित्राणां पवित्रं यो मङ्गलानां च मङ्गलम् ।
lines.iast: pavitrāṇāṃ pavitraṃ yō maṅgaḻānāṃ cha maṅgaḻam ।
lines.knda: ಪವಿತ್ರಾಣಾಂ ಪವಿತ್ರಂ ಯೋ ಮಂಗಳಾನಾಂ ಚ ಮಂಗಳಮ್ ।
lines.tel: పవిత్రాణాం పవిత్రం యో మంగళానాం చ మంగళమ్ ।
lines.tam: பவித்ராணாம் பவித்ரம் யோ மங்கள³ானாம் ச மங்கள³ம் ।
lines.guj: પવિત્રાણાં પવિત્રં યો મંગળાનાં ચ મંગળમ્ ।
lines.pan: ਪਵਿਤ੍ਰਾਣਾਂ ਪਵਿਤ੍ਰਂ ਯੋ ਮਂਗਲ਼ਾਨਾਂ ਚ ਮਂਗਲ਼ਮ੍ ।
lines.mr: पवित्राणां पवित्रं यो मंगलानां च मंगलम् ।
lines.meaning: He who is the purest of the pure, the most auspicious of all auspicious things...

lines.deva: दैवतं देवतानां च भूतानां योऽव्ययः पिता ॥
lines.iast: daivataṃ dēvatānāṃ cha bhūtānāṃ yō'vyayaḥ pitā ॥
lines.knda: ದೈವತಂ ದೇವತಾನಾಂ ಚ ಭೂತಾನಾಂ ಯೋಽವ್ಯಯಃ ಪಿತಾ ॥
lines.tel: దైవతం దేవతానాం చ భూతానాం యోఽవ్యయః పితా ॥
lines.tam: தை³வதம் தே³வதானாம் ச பூ⁴தானாம் யோவ்யய: பிதா ॥
lines.guj: દૈવતં દેવતાનાં ચ ભૂતાનાં યોઽવ્યયઃ પિતા ॥
lines.pan: ਦੈਵਤਂ ਦੇਵਤਾਨਾਂ ਚ ਭੂਤਾਨਾਂ ਯੋ਽ਵ੍ਯਯਃ ਪਿਤਾ ॥
lines.mr: दैवतं देवतानां च भूतानां योऽव्ययः पिता ॥
lines.ben: পবিত্রাণাং পবিত্রং যো মংগলানাং চ মংগলম্ ।
lines.mal: പവിത്രാണാം പവിത്രം യോ മംഗളാനാം ച മംഗളമ് ।
lines.meaning: The God of gods, the imperishable Father of all beings.
From whom all beings arise at the beginning of the cosmic cycle...
And into whom they dissolve again at the end of each cosmic age.
Of that primordial Lord of the worlds, of Jagannatha, O King...

lines.deva: विष्णोर्नाम सहस्रं मे श्रुणु पाप भयापहम् ॥
lines.iast: viṣṇōrnāma sahasraṃ mē śruṇu pāpa bhayāpaham ॥
lines.knda: ವಿಷ್ಣೋರ್ನಾಮ ಸಹಸ್ರಂ ಮೇ ಶ್ರುಣು ಪಾಪ ಭಯಾಪಹಮ್ ॥
lines.tel: విష్ణోర్నామ సహస్రం మే శ్రుణు పాప భయాపహమ్ ॥
lines.tam: விஷ்ணோர்னாம ஸஹஸ்ரம் மே ஶ்ருணு பாப ப⁴யாபஹம் ॥
lines.guj: વિષ્ણોર્નામ સહસ્રં મે શ્રુણુ પાપ ભયાપહમ્ ॥
lines.pan: ਵਿਸ਼੍ਣੋਰ੍ਨਾਮ ਸਹਸ੍ਰਂ ਮੇ ਸ਼੍ਰੁਣੁ ਪਾਪ ਭਯਾਪਹਮ੍ ॥
lines.mr: विष्णोर्नाम सहस्रं मे श्रुणु पाप भयापहम् ॥
lines.meaning: Hear from me the thousand names of Vishnu, which destroy sin and fear.
lines.note: This is a pivotal verse where Bhishma formally introduces the Sahasranama. He promises Yudhishthira that these names will remove all sins and fears.

lines.meaning: Those famous names of the Great Soul that are based on His attributes...
Which have been sung by the sages - these I shall recite for your welfare.
The Rishi of the thousand names is the great sage Veda Vyasa.
lines.note: This begins the viniyoga (application) portion that identifies the spiritual components of the stotra for ritual purposes.

lines.meaning: The meter (chandas) is Anushtup; the deity is the Lord, the son of Devaki (Krishna).
The bija (seed mantra) is 'Amritam Shudbhava'; the shakti (power) is Devaki-nandana (Krishna).
Trisama is the heart (hridayam) of this stotra; it is recited for peace and auspiciousness.
Vishnu, the Victorious, the Great Vishnu, the Powerful, the Great Lord...
I bow to the Supreme Being (Purushottama), who has many forms and who destroys demons.
lines.note: This concluding verse of the Poorva Peetika prepares for the main recitation. The devotee offers salutations to Vishnu who manifests in countless forms to protect dharma.

lines.meaning: Preliminary Nyasa - The ritual placement of mantras on the body performed before the main recitation to sanctify and prepare the practitioner.
lines.note: Nyasa literally means 'placing' or 'depositing'. This preliminary ritual invokes divine energies at specific points of the body, transforming the practitioner into a fit vessel for the sacred recitation.

lines.deva: अस्य श्री विष्णोर्दिव्य सहस्रनाम स्तोत्र महामन्त्रस्य ॥
lines.iast: asya śrī viṣṇōrdivya sahasranāma stōtra mahāmantrasya ॥
lines.knda: ಅಸ್ಯ ಶ್ರೀ ವಿಷ್ಣೋರ್ದಿವ್ಯ ಸಹಸ್ರನಾಮ ಸ್ತೋತ್ರ ಮಹಾಮಂತ್ರಸ್ಯ ॥
lines.tel: అస్య శ్రీ విష్ణోర్దివ్య సహస్రనామ స్తోత్ర మహామంత్రస్య ॥
lines.tam: அஸ்ய ஶ்ரீ விஷ்ணோர்தி³வ்ய ஸஹஸ்ரனாம ஸ்தோத்ர மஹாமந்த்ரஸ்ய ॥
lines.guj: અસ્ય શ્રી વિષ્ણોર્દિવ્ય સહસ્રનામ સ્તોત્ર મહામંત્રસ્ય ॥
lines.pan: ਅਸ੍ਯ ਸ਼੍ਰੀ ਵਿਸ਼੍ਣੋਰ੍ਦਿਵ੍ਯ ਸਹਸ੍ਰਨਾਮ ਸ੍ਤੋਤ੍ਰ ਮਹਾਮਂਤ੍ਰਸ੍ਯ ॥
lines.mr: अस्य श्री विष्णोर्दिव्य सहस्रनाम स्तोत्र महामंत्रस्य ॥
lines.meaning: Of this divine thousand-name hymn of Sri Vishnu, the great mantra - This opening declares the subject of the nyasa, establishing it as a mahāmantra (great mantra) of supreme spiritual potency.

samasaVibhaga.combinedMeaning: The great mantra that is the thousand-name hymn

lines.ben: অস্য় শ্রী বিষ্ণোর্দিব্য় সহস্রনাম স্তোত্র মহামংত্রস্য় ॥
lines.mal: അസ്യ ശ്രീ വിഷ്ണോര്ദിവ്യ സഹസ്രനാമ സ്തോത്ര മഹാമംത്രസ്യ ॥
lines.meaning: The Rishi (seer) is the divine Bhagavan Vedavyasa - The sage who revealed this mantra. Vedavyasa, compiler of the Vedas and Mahabharata, is honored as the seer through whom this sacred knowledge manifested.
lines.note: In Vedic tradition, every mantra has a rishi (seer who received it), chandas (meter), and devata (presiding deity). Acknowledging the rishi establishes the mantra's authentic lineage.

lines.meaning: The meter (chandas) is Anushtup - A Vedic meter of 32 syllables arranged in four padas of 8 syllables each. This is the most common meter for shlokas and stotras.
lines.note: Anushtup meter creates a rhythmic flow ideal for memorization and chanting. The Bhagavad Gita, much of the Mahabharata, and most stotras use this meter.

lines.meaning: The presiding deity (devata) is Sri Mahavishnu, the Supreme Self, Sri Narayana - The mantra's power flows from and leads to this supreme deity, identified here with three names emphasizing his glory (Sri), greatness (Maha), all-pervasiveness (Vishnu), and role as the ultimate refuge (Narayana).

etymology.meaning: The refuge of all beings; One who dwells in the waters of creation
alternates: One who moves in the hearts of beings

lines.meaning: The seed mantra (bija) is 'Amritamshudbhavo Bhanu' (He who is born from immortal rays, the radiant one) - The bija is the concentrated essence of the mantra's power, invoking Vishnu as the source of immortal light.
lines.note: Bija (seed) mantras contain the concentrated vibrational essence of the deity. Here, Vishnu is invoked as the source of immortality (amrita) and radiance (bhanu), connecting him to the sun and life-giving forces.

lines.meaning: The shakti (power) is 'Devaki Nandana Srashta' (The son of Devaki, the Creator) - This invokes the dynamic creative power of the mantra, connecting Vishnu's avatar as Krishna (Devaki's son) with his cosmic role as Creator.

etymology.dhatu: Devakī (mother's name) + nandana (son, one who gives joy)
etymology.meaning: The beloved son of Devaki; Sri Krishna
The Creator; One who projects forth creation

lines.meaning: The supreme mantra is 'Udbhava, Kshobhano Deva' (The Origin, the Agitator, the Luminous One) - This paramaomantra represents the highest essence, invoking Vishnu as the source of creation and the one who stirs the primordial waters into manifestation.

etymology.meaning: The Origin; One from whom all arises
The Agitator; One who stirs creation into being from the primordial stillness

lines.meaning: The kilaka (pin/lock) is 'Shankhabhrit Nandaki Chakri' (Bearer of the conch, wielder of Nandaka sword, holder of the discus) - The kilaka secures the mantra's power, here invoking Vishnu's iconic weapons that protect devotees.
lines.note: Kilaka literally means 'pin' or 'bolt'. It locks and releases the mantra's power. Vishnu's weapons - Panchajanya (conch), Nandaka (sword), and Sudarshana (discus) - symbolize protection, discrimination, and the power to destroy ignorance.

lines.meaning: The astra (weapon mantra) is 'Sharngadhanva Gadadhara' (Wielder of the Sharnga bow, bearer of the mace) - This protective formula invokes Vishnu's remaining weapons for spiritual defense.
The netra (eye mantra) is 'Rathangapani Rakshobhya' (He whose hand holds the chariot wheel, the indestructible protector) - This formula is placed on the eyes for divine vision and protection.

etymology.meaning: One whose hand holds the chariot wheel (Sudarshana chakra)
The unshakeable protector; One whose protection cannot be disturbed

lines.meaning: The kavacha (armor mantra) is 'Trisama Samaga Sama' (The essence of the three Sama hymns, knower of Sama, the Sama Veda itself) - This protective formula invokes Vishnu as the embodiment of sacred Vedic chants.
lines.note: The Sama Veda is the Veda of sacred songs. Trisama refers to the three principal Sama hymns (Devavratam, Brihat, Rathantaram). Invoking Vishnu as Sama itself creates spiritual armor of sacred sound.

etymology.meaning: One who is praised by the three principal Sama hymns
One who knows/sings the Sama Veda

lines.meaning: The yoni (source/womb mantra) is 'Ananda Parabrahma' (Bliss, the Supreme Brahman) - This formula invokes the ultimate source from which the mantra emerges, identifying Vishnu with absolute bliss and the highest reality.
lines.note: Yoni here means 'source' or 'origin'. The Taittiriya Upanishad declares 'ānando brahmeti vyajānāt' - Brahman is known as bliss. This establishes the mantra's origin in the blissful absolute.

lines.meaning: The digbandha (directional seal) is 'Ritu Sudarshana Kala' (The Season, the Beautiful-to-behold, Time itself) - This formula seals all directions, invoking Vishnu as the lord of cyclical time (seasons), divine vision, and cosmic time.

etymology.meaning: Season; One who is the cycle of seasons
Beautiful to behold; Also the name of Vishnu's discus
Time; The cosmic force that measures and moves all things

lines.meaning: The dhyana (meditation form) is 'Sri Vishvarupa' (The auspicious Universal Form) - The practitioner meditates on Vishnu's cosmic form that contains all of creation, as revealed to Arjuna in the Bhagavad Gita.
lines.note: The Vishvarupa is the cosmic form Vishnu/Krishna revealed in Bhagavad Gita Chapter 11, showing the entire universe within his divine body.

etymology.meaning: One whose form is the universe; The cosmic form containing all existence

lines.deva: श्री महाविष्णु प्रीत्यर्थे सहस्रनाम जपे पारायणे विनियोगः ।
lines.iast: śrī mahāviṣṇu prītyarthē sahasranāma japē pārāyaṇē viniyōgaḥ ।
lines.knda: ಶ್ರೀ ಮಹಾವಿಷ್ಣು ಪ್ರೀತ್ಯರ್ಥೇ ಸಹಸ್ರನಾಮ ಜಪೇ ಪಾರಾಯಣೇ ವಿನಿಯೋಗಃ ।
lines.tel: శ్రీ మహావిష్ణు ప్రీత్యర్థే సహస్రనామ జపే పారాయణే వినియోగః ।
lines.tam: ஶ்ரீ மஹாவிஷ்ணு ப்ரீத்யர்தே² ஸஹஸ்ரனாம ஜபே பாராயணே வினியோக:³ ।
lines.guj: શ્રી મહાવિષ્ણુ પ્રીત્યર્થે સહસ્રનામ જપે પારાયણે વિનિયોગઃ ।
lines.pan: ਸ਼੍ਰੀ ਮਹਾਵਿਸ਼੍ਣੁ ਪ੍ਰੀਤ੍ਯਰ੍ਥੇ ਸਹਸ੍ਰਨਾਮ ਜਪੇ ਪਾਰਾਯਣੇ ਵਿਨਿਯੋਗਃ ।
lines.mr: श्री महाविष्णु प्रीत्यर्थे सहस्रनाम जपे पारायणे विनियोगः ।
lines.meaning: The application (viniyoga) is: For the pleasure of Sri Mahavishnu, in the japa (repetition) and parayana (complete recitation) of the thousand names. This declares the purpose - to please the Lord through devoted chanting.
lines.note: Viniyoga means 'application' or 'dedication'. This concludes the Poorvanyasa by stating the purpose: the mantra is applied for the pleasure (prīti) of Vishnu through japa (meditative repetition) or parayana (complete recitation).

lines.ben: শ্রী মহাবিষ্ণু প্রীত্যর্থে সহস্রনাম জপে পারাযণে বিনিয়োগঃ ।
lines.mal: ശ്രീ മഹാവിഷ്ണു പ്രീത്യര്ഥേ സഹസ്രനാമ ജപേ പാരായണേ വിനിയോഗഃ ।
lines.meaning: Hand Placement (Karanyasa) - Ritual touching of divine names to the fingers, sanctifying the hands that will perform worship.
lines.note: Kara means 'hand'. In karanyasa, specific mantras are placed on each finger and part of the hand, transforming the hands into instruments of divine worship.

lines.meaning: With 'Vishvam Vishnur Vashatkara' (The Universe, Vishnu, the Sacrificial Call), salutations to the thumbs - The first three divine names are placed on both thumbs while touching them together.

etymology.meaning: The Universe; One who enters and pervades all
The Sacrificial Call personified; The essence of Vedic ritual

lines.meaning: With 'Amritamshudbhavo Bhanu' (Born from immortal rays, the Radiant One), salutations to the index fingers - These names invoking Vishnu as the source of light are placed on both index fingers.

etymology.meaning: One born from immortal rays; Connected to the moon and sun

lines.meaning: With 'Brahmanya Brahmakrit Brahma' (Friend of Brahmins, Creator of Brahma, Brahman itself), salutations to the middle fingers - These names establishing Vishnu's relationship with sacred knowledge are placed on both middle fingers.

etymology.meaning: Friend of Brahmins; Favorable to sacred knowledge and those who pursue it
Creator of Brahma; One who creates the creator
The Supreme Reality; The Vast; Brahman

lines.meaning: With 'Suvarnabindu Rakshobhya' (The Golden Point, the Unshakeable Protector), salutations to the ring fingers - These names are placed on both ring fingers.

etymology.meaning: The Golden Point; The precious essence; The golden drop of consciousness

lines.meaning: With 'Nimisha Animisha Sragvi' (The Blinking One, the Unblinking, the Garlanded), salutations to the little fingers - These paradoxical names are placed on both little fingers.

etymology.meaning: One who blinks; Represents the manifest creation that appears and disappears
The Unblinking; Ever-watchful; The eternal witness
The Garlanded One; Wearer of the Vaijayanti garland

lines.deva: रथाङ्गपाणि रक्षोभ्य इति करतल करपृष्ठाभ्यां नमः
lines.iast: rathāṅgapāṇi rakṣōbhya iti karatala karapṛṣṭhābhyāṃ namaḥ
lines.knda: ರಥಾಂಗಪಾಣಿ ರಕ್ಷೋಭ್ಯ ಇತಿ ಕರತಲ ಕರಪೃಷ್ಠಾಭ್ಯಾಂ ನಮಃ
lines.tel: రథాంగపాణి రక్షోభ్య ఇతి కరతల కరపృష్ఠాభ్యాం నమః
lines.tam: ரதா²ங்க³பாணி ரக்ஷோப்⁴ய இதி கரதல கரப்ருஷ்டா²ப்⁴யாம் நம:
lines.guj: રથાંગપાણિ રક્ષોભ્ય ઇતિ કરતલ કરપૃષ્ઠાભ્યાં નમઃ
lines.pan: ਰਥਾਂਗਪਾਣਿ ਰਕ੍ਸ਼ੋਭ੍ਯ ਇਤਿ ਕਰਤਲ ਕਰਪ੍ਰੁਰੁਇਸ਼੍ਠਾਭ੍ਯਾਂ ਨਮਃ
lines.mr: रथांगपाणि रक्षोभ्य इति करतल करपृष्ठाभ्यां नमः
lines.meaning: With 'Rathangapani Rakshobhya' (Discus-handed, Unshakeable Protector), salutations to the palms and backs of hands - This completes karanyasa by sanctifying both surfaces of the hands.

etymology.meaning: One holding the chariot wheel (Sudarshana chakra) in hand

lines.ben: রথাংগপাণি রক্ষোভ্য় ইতি করতল করপৃষ্ঠাভ্য়াং নমঃ
lines.mal: രഥാംഗപാണി രക്ഷോഭ്യ ഇതി കരതല കരപൃഷ്ഠാഭ്യാം നമഃ
lines.meaning: Body Placement (Anganyasa) - Ritual touching of divine names to six parts of the body (heart, head, tuft, armor/chest, eyes, weapon/snap), invoking divine protection.
lines.note: Anga means 'limb' or 'body part'. In anganyasa, mantras are placed on the heart, head, shikha (tuft), kavacha (chest/armor), netra (eyes), and astra (the surrounding space, sealed with a finger snap).

lines.deva: सुव्रतः सुमुखः सूक्ष्म इति ज्ञानाय हृदयाय नमः
lines.iast: suvrataḥ sumukhaḥ sūkṣma iti jñānāya hṛdayāya namaḥ
lines.knda: ಸುವ್ರತಃ ಸುಮುಖಃ ಸೂಕ್ಷ್ಮ ಇತಿ ಜ್ಞಾನಾಯ ಹೃದಯಾಯ ನಮಃ
lines.tel: సువ్రతః సుముఖః సూక్ష్మ ఇతి జ్ఞానాయ హృదయాయ నమః
lines.tam: ஸுவ்ரத: ஸுமுக:² ஸூக்ஷ்ம இதி ஜ்ஞானாய ஹ்ருத³யாய நம:
lines.guj: સુવ્રતઃ સુમુખઃ સૂક્ષ્મ ઇતિ જ્ઞાનાય હૃદયાય નમઃ
lines.pan: ਸੁਵ੍ਰਤਃ ਸੁਮੁਖਃ ਸੂਕ੍ਸ਼੍ਮ ਇਤਿ ਜ੍ਞਾਨਾਯ ਹ੍ਰੁਰੁਇਦਯਾਯ ਨਮਃ
lines.mr: सुव्रतः सुमुखः सूक्ष्म इति ज्ञानाय हृदयाय नमः
lines.meaning: With 'Suvrata Sumukha Sukshma' (Of excellent vows, beautiful-faced, subtle), for Knowledge, salutations to the Heart - These names are placed on the heart, the seat of spiritual knowledge.
lines.note: The heart (hridaya) is associated with jnana (knowledge) as it is considered the seat of inner wisdom and the place where the Atman dwells.

etymology.meaning: One of excellent vows; One who perfectly observes sacred duties
Beautiful-faced; One with a gracious countenance
The Subtle; Beyond gross perception; The innermost essence

lines.deva: सहस्रमूर्तिः विश्वात्मा इति ऐश्वर्याय शिरसे स्वाहा
lines.iast: sahasramūrtiḥ viśvātmā iti aiśvaryāya śirasē svāhā
lines.knda: ಸಹಸ್ರಮೂರ್ತಿಃ ವಿಶ್ವಾತ್ಮಾ ಇತಿ ಐಶ್ವರ್ಯಾಯ ಶಿರಸೇ ಸ್ವಾಹಾ
lines.tel: సహస్రమూర్తిః విశ్వాత్మా ఇతి ఐశ్వర్యాయ శిరసే స్వాహా
lines.tam: ஸஹஸ்ரமூர்தி: விஶ்வாத்மா இதி ஐஶ்வர்யாய ஶிரஸே ஸ்வாஹா
lines.guj: સહસ્રમૂર્તિઃ વિશ્વાત્મા ઇતિ ઐશ્વર્યાય શિરસે સ્વાહા
lines.pan: ਸਹਸ੍ਰਮੂਰ੍ਤਿਃ ਵਿਸ਼੍ਵਾਤ੍ਮਾ ਇਤਿ ਐਸ਼੍ਵਰ੍ਯਾਯ ਸ਼ਿਰਸੇ ਸ੍ਵਾਹਾ
lines.mr: सहस्रमूर्तिः विश्वात्मा इति ऐश्वर्याय शिरसे स्वाहा
lines.ben: সুব্রতঃ সুমুখঃ সূক্ষ্ম ইতি জ্ঞানায় হৃদয়ায় নমঃ
lines.mal: സുവ്രതഃ സുമുഖഃ സൂക്ഷ്മ ഇതി ജ്ഞാനായ ഹൃദയായ നമഃ
lines.meaning: With 'Sahasramurti Vishvatma' (Thousand-formed, Soul of the Universe), for Sovereignty, 'Svaha' to the Head - These names are placed on the head, the seat of lordship and authority.
lines.note: The head (shiras) is associated with aishvarya (divine sovereignty/lordship). 'Svaha' is the oblation call, offering the mantra to the deity.

etymology.meaning: One with a thousand forms; Having innumerable manifestations
The Soul of the Universe; The inner Self of all beings

lines.deva: सहस्रार्चिः सप्तजिह्व इति शक्त्यै शिखायै वषट्
lines.iast: sahasrārchiḥ saptajihva iti śaktyai śikhāyai vaṣaṭ
lines.knda: ಸಹಸ್ರಾರ್ಚಿಃ ಸಪ್ತಜಿಹ್ವ ಇತಿ ಶಕ್ತ್ಯೈ ಶಿಖಾಯೈ ವಷಟ್
lines.tel: సహస్రార్చిః సప్తజిహ్వ ఇతి శక్త్యై శిఖాయై వషట్
lines.tam: ஸஹஸ்ரார்சி: ஸப்தஜிஹ்வ இதி ஶக்த்யை ஶிகா²யை வஷட்
lines.guj: સહસ્રાર્ચિઃ સપ્તજિહ્વ ઇતિ શક્ત્યૈ શિખાયૈ વષટ્
lines.pan: ਸਹਸ੍ਰਾਰ੍ਚਿਃ ਸਪ੍ਤਜਿਹ੍ਵ ਇਤਿ ਸ਼ਕ੍ਤ੍ਯੈ ਸ਼ਿਖਾਯੈ ਵਸ਼ਟ੍
lines.mr: सहस्रार्चिः सप्तजिह्व इति शक्त्यै शिखायै वषट्
lines.ben: সহস্রমূর্তিঃ বিশ্বাত্মা ইতি ঐশ্বর্য়ায় শিরসে স্বাহা
lines.mal: സഹസ്രമൂര്തിഃ വിശ്വാത്മാ ഇതി ഐശ്വര്യായ ശിരസേ സ്വാഹാ
lines.meaning: With 'Sahasrarchi Saptajihva' (Thousand-rayed, Seven-tongued), for Power, 'Vashat' to the Topknot - These names invoking divine energy are placed on the shikha (tuft of hair).
lines.note: The shikha (topknot) is associated with shakti (divine power). The seven tongues refer to the seven flames of Agni (fire), representing transformative energy. 'Vashat' is a Vedic offering call.

etymology.meaning: One with a thousand rays; Infinitely radiant
Seven-tongued; Like fire with its seven flames

lines.ben: সহস্রার্চিঃ সপ্তজিহ্ব ইতি শক্ত্য়ৈ শিখায়ৈ বষট্
lines.mal: സഹസ്രാര്ചിഃ സപ്തജിഹ്വ ഇതി ശക്ത്യൈ ശിഖായൈ വഷട്
lines.meaning: With 'Trisama Samaga Sama' (Praised by three Samas, knower of Sama, the Sama itself), for Strength, 'Hum' to the Armor/Chest - These Vedic names create protective armor around the chest.
lines.note: The kavacha (armor/chest) is associated with bala (strength). 'Hum' is a powerful bija mantra that invokes protection. The Sama Veda's sacred melodies form spiritual armor.

etymology.meaning: One praised by the three principal Sama hymns (Devavratam, Brihat, Rathantaram)
The Sama Veda itself; Sacred song; Harmony

lines.meaning: With 'Rathangapani Rakshobhya' (Discus-handed, Unshakeable Protector), 'Vaushat' to the Eyes - These protective names are placed on both eyes for divine vision.
lines.note: The netra (eyes) receive protection for spiritual vision. 'Vaushat' is a Vedic ritual exclamation. The Sudarshana chakra (discus) symbolizes divine vision that sees all.

lines.meaning: With 'Sharngadhanva Gadadhara' (Bow-wielder, Mace-bearer), for Valor, 'Phat' to the Astra (weapon/surroundings) - These weapon-names seal the surrounding space with a finger snap.
lines.note: The astra (weapon) placement is associated with virya (valor/potency). 'Phat' is a bija that dispels negative forces. A finger snap accompanies this, creating a protective barrier.

etymology.dhatu: śārṅga (name of the divine bow) + dhanvan (bow-wielder)

lines.meaning: With 'Ritu Sudarshana Kala' (Season, Beautiful-visioned, Time), the directional seal (Digbandha) - These time-names seal all ten directions, completing the protective enclosure.
lines.note: Digbandha seals all directions (the four cardinal, four intermediate, plus zenith and nadir). Vishnu as Time encompasses all directions and moments.

etymology.meaning: Season; The cyclic movement of time
Beautiful to behold; Also the divine discus
Time; The cosmic force that governs all change

lines.meaning: Meditation (Dhyanam) - The section heading introducing the meditation verses that follow, where the practitioner visualizes the divine form before beginning the recitation.
lines.note: Having completed the nyasa rituals that prepare the body, the practitioner now enters dhyana (meditation), visualizing the divine form. This transitions from physical preparation to mental contemplation.

lines.meaning: In the region of the Milk Ocean (Kshirasagara), on a shore glittering with pure gems, on sands made of pearls...
lines.note: This begins the first dhyana shloka describing Vishnu reclining on Ananta Shesha in the cosmic Milk Ocean. The Kshirasagara is one of the seven cosmic oceans in Hindu cosmology.

lines.meaning: ...seated on a throne fashioned from garlands, His body adorned with pearls resembling crystal gems...
...with brilliant white clouds above, abundant and arranged, showering liberating nectar (amrita)...
lines.note: The verse uses beautiful alliteration (abhrai-radabhrai) to describe the celestial clouds raining nectar.

lines.meaning: ...may that blissful Mukunda, holding discus, lotus, mace and conch in His hands, purify us!
lines.note: This completes the first dhyana shloka (verses 105-108). Mukunda is invoked as the liberator, holding His four iconic items: chakra (discus), padma (lotus), gada (mace), and shankha (conch).

etymology.meaning: The Giver of Liberation; One who bestows moksha

lines.deva: भूः पादौ यस्य नाभिर्विय-दसुर निलश्चन्द्र सूर्यौ च नेत्रे
lines.iast: bhūḥ pādau yasya nābhirviya-dasura nilaśchandra sūryau cha nētrē
lines.knda: ಭೂಃ ಪಾದೌ ಯಸ್ಯ ನಾಭಿರ್ವಿಯ-ದಸುರ ನಿಲಶ್ಚಂದ್ರ ಸೂರ್ಯೌ ಚ ನೇತ್ರೇ
lines.tel: భూః పాదౌ యస్య నాభిర్వియ-దసుర నిలశ్చంద్ర సూర్యౌ చ నేత్రే
lines.tam: பூ⁴: பாதௌ³ யஸ்ய நாபி⁴ர்விய-த³ஸுர நிலஶ்சந்த்³ர ஸூர்யௌ ச நேத்ரே
lines.guj: ભૂઃ પાદૌ યસ્ય નાભિર્વિય-દસુર નિલશ્ચંદ્ર સૂર્યૌ ચ નેત્રે
lines.pan: ਭੂਃ ਪਾਦੌ ਯਸ੍ਯ ਨਾਭਿਰ੍ਵਿਯ-ਦਸੁਰ ਨਿਲਸ਼੍ਚਂਦ੍ਰ ਸੂਰ੍ਯੌ ਚ ਨੇਤ੍ਰੇ
lines.mr: भूः पादौ यस्य नाभिर्विय-दसुर निलश्चंद्र सूर्यौ च नेत्रे
lines.meaning: The Earth is His feet, the sky is His navel, the wind is His breath, the Moon and Sun are His two eyes...
lines.note: This begins the famous Vishvarupa (Cosmic Form) meditation. Each part of the universe corresponds to a part of Vishnu's cosmic body, echoing the Purusha Sukta of the Rig Veda.

lines.ben: ভূঃ পাদৌ যস্য় নাভির্বিয়-দসুর নিলশ্চংদ্র সূর্য়ৌ চ নেত্রে
lines.mal: ഭൂഃ പാദൌ യസ്യ നാഭിർവിയ-ദസുര നിലശ്ചംദ്ര സൂര്യൌ ച നേത്രേ
lines.meaning: ...the directions are His ears, heaven is His head, fire is His mouth, the ocean is His belly...

lines.deva: अन्तःस्थं यस्य विश्वं सुर नरखगगोभोगि गन्धर्वदैत्यैः
lines.iast: antaḥsthaṃ yasya viśvaṃ sura narakhagagōbhōgi gandharvadaityaiḥ
lines.knda: ಅಂತಃಸ್ಥಂ ಯಸ್ಯ ವಿಶ್ವಂ ಸುರ ನರಖಗಗೋಭೋಗಿ ಗಂಧರ್ವದೈತ್ಯೈಃ
lines.tel: అంతఃస్థం యస్య విశ్వం సుర నరఖగగోభోగి గంధర్వదైత్యైః
lines.tam: அந்த:ஸ்த²ம் யஸ்ய விஶ்வம் ஸுர நரக²க³கோ³போ⁴கி³ க³ந்த⁴ர்வதை³த்யை:
lines.guj: અંતઃસ્થં યસ્ય વિશ્વં સુર નરખગગોભોગિ ગંધર્વદૈત્યૈઃ
lines.pan: ਅਂਤਃਸ੍ਥਂ ਯਸ੍ਯ ਵਿਸ਼੍ਵਂ ਸੁਰ ਨਰਖਗਗੋਭੋਗਿ ਗਂਧਰ੍ਵਦੈਤ੍ਯੈਃ
lines.mr: अंतःस्थं यस्य विश्वं सुर नरखगगोभोगि गंधर्वदैत्यैः
lines.meaning: ...within whom resides the entire universe - devas, humans, birds, cattle, serpents, gandharvas, and daityas...

lines.deva: चित्रं रं रम्यते तं त्रिभुवन वपुशं विष्णुमीशं नमामि ॥
lines.iast: chitraṃ raṃ ramyatē taṃ tribhuvana vapuśaṃ viṣṇumīśaṃ namāmi ॥
lines.knda: ಚಿತ್ರಂ ರಂ ರಮ್ಯತೇ ತಂ ತ್ರಿಭುವನ ವಪುಶಂ ವಿಷ್ಣುಮೀಶಂ ನಮಾಮಿ ॥
lines.tel: చిత్రం రం రమ్యతే తం త్రిభువన వపుశం విష్ణుమీశం నమామి ॥
lines.tam: சித்ரம் ரம் ரம்யதே தம் த்ரிபு⁴வன வபுஶம் விஷ்ணுமீஶம் நமாமி ॥
lines.guj: ચિત્રં રં રમ્યતે તં ત્રિભુવન વપુશં વિષ્ણુમીશં નમામિ ॥
lines.pan: ਚਿਤ੍ਰਂ ਰਂ ਰਮ੍ਯਤੇ ਤਂ ਤ੍ਰਿਭੁਵਨ ਵਪੁਸ਼ਂ ਵਿਸ਼੍ਣੁਮੀਸ਼ਂ ਨਮਾਮਿ ॥
lines.mr: चित्रं रं रम्यते तं त्रिभुवन वपुशं विष्णुमीशं नमामि ॥
lines.ben: অংতঃস্থং যস্য় বিশ্বং সুর নরখগগোভোগি গংধর্বদৈত্য়ৈঃ
lines.mal: അംതഃസ്ഥം യസ്യ വിശ്വം സുര നരഖഗഗോഭോഗി ഗംധർവദൈത്യൈഃ
lines.meaning: ...I bow to that wonderful, enchanting Vishnu, the Lord, whose body is the three worlds!
lines.note: This completes the Vishvarupa dhyana (verses 110-113). Tribhuvana refers to the three worlds: earth (bhur), atmosphere (bhuvar), and heaven (svar).

lines.meaning: Om! Salutations to the Divine Lord Vasudeva!
lines.note: This is the Dwadashakshari (12-syllable) mantra, one of the most sacred Vaishnava mantras. It is considered the essence of the Sahasranama itself.

etymology.meaning: Son of Vasudeva (Krishna); The Divine who dwells in all beings; The illuminating presence within
alternates: One in whom all beings dwell

lines.meaning: Of peaceful form, reclining on the serpent (Ananta Shesha), lotus-naveled, Lord of the gods...
lines.note: This begins one of the most famous and widely recited dhyana shlokas in Hinduism. Each epithet paints a vivid picture of Vishnu in His cosmic repose.

etymology.meaning: One whose form embodies peace; The embodiment of tranquility
One who reclines on the serpent Ananta Shesha
Lotus-naveled; From whose navel the cosmic lotus (with Brahma) emerges
Lord of the gods; The supreme deity

lines.meaning: ...the support of the universe, vast as the sky, cloud-complexioned, with auspicious limbs...

etymology.meaning: The support of the entire universe
Cloud-complexioned; Having the dark blue color of rain clouds
One with auspicious limbs; Of beautiful, blessed form

lines.meaning: ...beloved of Lakshmi, lotus-eyed, attainable through meditation in the hearts of yogis...

etymology.meaning: The beloved of Lakshmi; Consort of the goddess of prosperity
Lotus-eyed; Having eyes beautiful as lotus petals
One who is attainable through meditation in the hearts of yogis

lines.meaning: ...I bow to Vishnu, the remover of the fear of worldly existence, the sole Lord of all worlds!
lines.note: This completes the famous Shantakaram shloka (verses 116-119), perhaps the most recited Vishnu dhyana verse.

etymology.meaning: The remover of the fear of samsara (cycle of birth and death)
The sole Lord of all worlds; The one supreme ruler

lines.meaning: Dark as a rain cloud, clad in yellow silk garments...

etymology.meaning: Dark as a rain cloud; Of beautiful dark complexion

lines.meaning: ...bearing the Srivatsa mark on His chest, His body illuminated by the Kaustubha gem...
lines.note: Srivatsa is a distinctive curl of hair on Vishnu's chest, marking where Lakshmi eternally resides. Kaustubha is the divine jewel that emerged from the churning of the Milk Ocean.

lines.meaning: ...endowed with all auspiciousness, with eyes long as lotus petals...

etymology.meaning: Endowed with all merit and holiness
One with eyes long and beautiful as white lotus petals

lines.meaning: ...I bow to Vishnu, the sole Lord of all worlds!
lines.note: This completes the Megha Shyamam dhyana (verses 121-124).

lines.deva: नमः समस्त भूतानां आदि भूताय भूभृते ।
lines.iast: namaḥ samasta bhūtānāṃ ādi bhūtāya bhūbhṛtē ।
lines.knda: ನಮಃ ಸಮಸ್ತ ಭೂತಾನಾಂ ಆದಿ ಭೂತಾಯ ಭೂಭೃತೇ ।
lines.tel: నమః సమస్త భూతానాం ఆది భూతాయ భూభృతే ।
lines.tam: நம: ஸமஸ்த பூ⁴தானாம் ஆதி³ பூ⁴தாய பூ⁴ப்⁴ருதே ।
lines.guj: નમઃ સમસ્ત ભૂતાનાં આદિ ભૂતાય ભૂભૃતે ।
lines.pan: ਨਮਃ ਸਮਸ੍ਤ ਭੂਤਾਨਾਂ ਆਦਿ ਭੂਤਾਯ ਭੂਭ੍ਰੁਰੁਇਤੇ ।
lines.mr: नमः समस्त भूतानां आदि भूताय भूभृते ।
lines.meaning: Salutations to the primordial Being of all beings, the supporter of the Earth...

etymology.meaning: The primordial Being; The first cause of all existence
Supporter of the Earth; Often refers to the Varaha (boar) avatara who lifted the Earth

lines.ben: নমঃ সমস্ত ভূতানাং আদি ভূতায় ভূভৃতে ।
lines.mal: നമഃ സമസ്ത ഭൂതാനാം ആദി ഭൂതായ ഭൂഭൃതേ ।
lines.meaning: ...to Vishnu of many forms yet formless, the supremely powerful!
lines.note: This completes the Namah Samasta dhyana (verses 126-127). 'Anekarupa rupaya' paradoxically praises Him as both having countless forms and being the formless essence behind all forms.

etymology.meaning: One whose form is the essence of many forms; Both manifest in countless forms and transcendent
The supremely powerful Vishnu; The mighty all-pervader

lines.meaning: With conch and discus, wearing crown and earrings...
lines.note: This begins a dhyana describing Vishnu in His royal four-armed form with iconic attributes.

lines.meaning: ...wearing yellow garments, with eyes like lotuses in a lake...

etymology.meaning: One with eyes like lotuses growing in a lake

lines.meaning: ...with the Kaustubha gem adorning His chest along with a garland...
...I bow my head to Vishnu, the four-armed one!
lines.note: This completes the Sashankha Chakram dhyana (verses 129-132). Chaturbhuja (four-armed) is the classic iconographic form of Vishnu.

etymology.meaning: The four-armed one; Holding conch, discus, mace, and lotus

lines.meaning: In the shade of the Parijata tree, upon a golden throne...
lines.note: This begins a dhyana describing Krishna in Dwaraka. The Parijata is the celestial wish-fulfilling tree that Krishna brought from Indra's heaven for Satyabhama.

lines.meaning: ...seated, cloud-complexioned, with long eyes, beautifully adorned...

etymology.meaning: Dark as a rain cloud; Of beautiful dark complexion

lines.meaning: Moon-faced, four-armed, with the Srivatsa mark on His chest...

etymology.meaning: Moon-faced; With a face beautiful and soothing as the moon

lines.meaning: ...I take refuge in that Krishna, accompanied by Rukmini and Satyabhama!
lines.note: This completes the final dhyana (verses 134-138), depicting Krishna as the royal Lord of Dwaraka with His two principal queens, Rukmini and Satyabhama. This concludes the Dhyanam section, preparing the devotee for the main Stotram.

lines.meaning: The Hymn of Praise - The main body of one thousand divine names
lines.note: This section contains the 1008 names of Lord Vishnu, traditionally organized into 108 shlokas. Each name reveals a divine attribute, cosmic function, or philosophical truth about the Supreme Being.

lines.meaning: Salutations to Hari (the Remover of sins), the primordial sound Om
lines.note: The sacred invocation combining Hari (one who removes sins and sorrows) with Om (the cosmic sound representing Brahman). This marks the auspicious beginning of the recitation.

lines.meaning: He is the Universe itself, the All-pervading One, the Embodiment of Sacrifice, the Lord of past, present, and future
lines.note: This is the opening shloka of the Sahasranama proper, beginning with Vishvam - establishing that the Lord is both the material and efficient cause of the universe.

etymology.explanation: One who has entered into everything; the cosmos itself as His body
One who pervades everything; who entered the universe and dwells in all beings
The sacred utterance 'Vaṣaṭ' used in Vedic sacrifices; He is the essence of all yajñas

etymology.meaning: Lord + of what was, will be, and is
etymology.explanation: The Master of all three times - past (bhūta), future (bhavya), and present (bhavat)

lines.meaning: The Creator of beings, the Sustainer of beings, Pure Existence, the Inner Soul of all, the Nurturer of beings
lines.note: Shloka 1 complete. These first nine names establish the fundamental relationship between Vishnu and creation - He is the universe, pervades it, creates beings, sustains them, is their essence, and causes them to flourish.

etymology.explanation: The Creator of all beings; He who brings forth all creatures into existence
The Sustainer of all beings; He who nourishes and maintains all creation
Pure Existence itself; the state of being from which all existence arises
The Inner Self of all beings; the consciousness animating all creatures
The Nurturer who causes all beings to grow, thrive and prosper

lines.meaning: The Pure Self, the Supreme Self, and the Ultimate Goal of the liberated ones

etymology.explanation: One whose nature is absolutely pure; untouched by the impurities of māyā
The Supreme Self; the highest consciousness distinct from individual souls
The highest destination of those who have attained liberation (mokṣa)

lines.deva: अव्ययः पुरुषः साक्षी क्षेत्रज्ञोऽक्षर एव च ॥
lines.iast: avyayaḥ puruṣaḥ sākṣī kṣētrajñō'kṣara ēva cha ॥
lines.knda: ಅವ್ಯಯಃ ಪುರುಷಃ ಸಾಕ್ಷೀ ಕ್ಷೇತ್ರಜ್ಞೋಽಕ್ಷರ ಏವ ಚ ॥
lines.tel: అవ్యయః పురుషః సాక్షీ క్షేత్రజ్ఞోఽక్షర ఏవ చ ॥
lines.tam: அவ்யய: புருஷ: ஸாக்ஷீ க்ஷேத்ரஜ்ஞோக்ஷர ஏவ ச ॥
lines.guj: અવ્યયઃ પુરુષઃ સાક્ષી ક્ષેત્રજ્ઞોઽક્ષર એવ ચ ॥
lines.pan: ਅਵ੍ਯਯਃ ਪੁਰੁਸ਼ਃ ਸਾਕ੍ਸ਼ੀ ਕ੍ਸ਼ੇਤ੍ਰਜ੍ਞੋ਽ਕ੍ਸ਼ਰ ਏਵ ਚ ॥
lines.mr: अव्ययः पुरुषः साक्षी क्षेत्रज्ञोऽक्षर एव च ॥
lines.meaning: The Imperishable One, the Cosmic Person, the Witness, the Knower of the Field, and the Immutable
lines.note: Shloka 2 complete. These names emphasize the eternal, witnessing, and imperishable nature of the Divine.

etymology.explanation: One who never diminishes or decays; eternally unchanging
One who dwells in the body-city; or the Complete Being who fills all
The direct Witness of everything; who sees all without being involved
The Knower of all fields (bodies); as described in Bhagavad Gita Chapter 13
The Imperishable One; also represents the sacred syllable Om

lines.meaning: The Yoga itself, the Leader of those who know Yoga, the Lord of Pradhana (primordial matter) and Purusha (souls)

etymology.explanation: Yoga itself - the means of union with the Divine; He is the goal and the path
The Supreme Guide of all yogis and knowers of divine union
Lord of both Pradhana (Prakṛti/matter) and Purusha (individual souls) - the Sāṃkhya concept

lines.meaning: He who has the form of Man-Lion (Narasimha), the Glorious One, Keshava (slayer of Keshi/the long-haired one), the Supreme Person
lines.note: Shloka 3 complete. This shloka introduces key avatāra names and the famous epithet Purushottama.

etymology.explanation: He who assumed the half-man, half-lion form to protect His devotee Prahlada
Possessor of all auspiciousness; the eternal consort of Goddess Lakshmi

alternates: क (ka=Brahma) + अ (a=Vishnu) + ईश (īśa=Shiva) - Lord of the Trinity
etymology.explanation: Slayer of demon Keshi; or One with beautiful hair; or Lord of Brahma, Vishnu, Shiva
The Supreme Person, beyond both the perishable and imperishable - as described in Bhagavad Gita 15.18

lines.meaning: The All, the Destroyer, the Auspicious, the Immovable, the Origin of beings, the Imperishable Treasure

etymology.explanation: The All - He who is everything and in everything
The Destroyer of the sins of those who worship Him

etymology.meaning: to lie, to rest; or auspiciousness
etymology.explanation: The Auspicious One; source of all that is good and blessed
The Immovable One; firm and unchanging like a pillar
The Primordial Source of all beings
The Inexhaustible Treasure; the eternal storehouse of all that is precious

lines.meaning: The Self-born, the One who nurtures, the Supporter, the Source, the Almighty Lord, the Supreme Controller
lines.note: Shloka 4 complete. These names establish the divine as the ultimate cause, sustainer, and ruler of creation.

etymology.explanation: One who manifests of His own will; who incarnates for the welfare of the world

etymology.meaning: to cause to be, to nurture
etymology.explanation: One who nurtures and brings beings into existence
The Supporter and Protector of the entire universe
The Origin from whom all beings emerge
The Almighty Master; One who excels in power
The Supreme Controller; the omnipotent Lord

lines.meaning: The Self-existent, the Bestower of happiness, the Son of Aditi (the Sun), the Lotus-eyed, the One of great resounding voice

etymology.explanation: The Self-existent One who has no cause; self-manifested
The Bestower of happiness and peace
Born as Vamana, son of Aditi; also represents the solar deity within the sun
The Lotus-eyed One; whose eyes are beautiful like lotus petals
One whose voice (as the Vedas) resonates throughout the universe

lines.meaning: Without beginning or end, the Creator, the Ordainer, the Highest Support
lines.note: Shloka 5 complete. This shloka emphasizes the eternal nature and creative/sustaining powers of the Divine.

etymology.explanation: One who has neither beginning nor end; eternal
The Creator who establishes the universe; the one who places all in order
The Ordainer of destiny; who dispenses the fruits of karma
The Supreme Support; the highest among all that sustains

lines.meaning: The Immeasurable, the Lord of the senses (Hrishikesha), the Lotus-naveled, the Lord of the immortals

etymology.explanation: One who cannot be measured or known through any means of knowledge
Lord of the senses; one who controls the senses of all beings
One from whose navel emerged the lotus that bore Brahma the Creator
The Lord of the Devas (gods); master of all immortals

lines.meaning: The Architect of the universe, Manu (the thinker), the Shaper, the Largest, the Ancient, the Unchanging
lines.note: Shloka 6 complete. This shloka emphasizes the cosmic creative powers and eternal nature of Vishnu.

etymology.explanation: The Architect of the entire cosmos; creator of all forms
The Thinker; the cosmic mind from which all thought originates
The Divine Craftsman who shapes all forms; the cosmic sculptor
The Largest; the most immense - refers to the cosmic form (Virat)
The Most Ancient; existing from time immemorial
The Unchanging; the eternal constant like the pole star

lines.meaning: The Incomprehensible, the Eternal, Krishna (the Dark/All-attractive One), the Red-eyed, the Destroyer of enemies

etymology.explanation: One who cannot be grasped by the senses or the mind
The Eternal One; existing in all times without change
The All-attractive One who draws all beings to Himself; or the one with a divine dark complexion
The Red-eyed One; eyes reddened by compassion or divine radiance
The Destroyer who annihilates enemies of devotees at the time of dissolution

lines.meaning: The Abundant, the Abode of the three worlds, the Pure, the Auspicious, the Supreme
lines.note: Shloka 7 complete. This shloka includes the famous name Krishna and emphasizes purity and auspiciousness.

etymology.explanation: The Abundant One; infinitely wealthy in all divine attributes
The Abode that encompasses all three worlds and directions
The Most Pure; one who purifies all who remember Him
The Supreme Auspiciousness; the highest source of all that is blessed

lines.deva: ईशानः प्राणदः प्राणो ज्येष्ठः श्रेष्ठः प्रजापतिः ।
lines.iast: īśānaḥ prāṇadaḥ prāṇō jyēṣṭhaḥ śrēṣṭhaḥ prajāpatiḥ ।
lines.knda: ಈಶಾನಃ ಪ್ರಾಣದಃ ಪ್ರಾಣೋ ಜ್ಯೇಷ್ಠಃ ಶ್ರೇಷ್ಠಃ ಪ್ರಜಾಪತಿಃ ।
lines.tel: ఈశానః ప్రాణదః ప్రాణో జ్యేష్ఠః శ్రేష్ఠః ప్రజాపతిః ।
lines.tam: ஈஶான: ப்ராணத:³ ப்ராணோ ஜ்யேஷ்ட:² ஶ்ரேஷ்ட:² ப்ரஜாபதி: ।
lines.guj: ઈશાનઃ પ્રાણદઃ પ્રાણો જ્યેષ્ઠઃ શ્રેષ્ઠઃ પ્રજાપતિઃ ।
lines.pan: ਈਸ਼ਾਨਃ ਪ੍ਰਾਣਦਃ ਪ੍ਰਾਣੋ ਜ੍ਯੇਸ਼੍ਠਃ ਸ਼੍ਰੇਸ਼੍ਠਃ ਪ੍ਰਜਾਪਤਿਃ ।
lines.mr: ईशानः प्राणदः प्राणो ज्येष्ठः श्रेष्ठः प्रजापतिः ।
lines.meaning: The Ruler, the Giver of life, the Life-force itself, the Eldest, the Most Excellent, the Lord of creatures

etymology.explanation: The Supreme Ruler; one who controls everything
The Bestower of life-force to all living beings
Life itself; the cosmic vital force animating all
The Eldest; existing before all creation
The Most Excellent; superior to all in every way
Lord of all creatures; the progenitor and protector of all beings

lines.ben: ঈশানঃ প্রাণদঃ প্রাণো জ্য়েষ্ঠঃ শ্রেষ্ঠঃ প্রজাপতিঃ ।
lines.mal: ഈശാനഃ പ്രാണദഃ പ്രാണോ ജ്യേഷ്ഠഃ ശ്രേഷ്ഠഃ പ്രജാപതിഃ ।
lines.meaning: The Golden Womb (cosmic egg), the Womb of the earth, Madhava (Lord of Lakshmi), the Slayer of Madhu
lines.note: Shloka 8 complete. This shloka features the cosmically significant name Hiranyagarbha and the beloved names Madhava and Madhusudana.

etymology.explanation: The Golden Womb; the cosmic egg from which all creation emerged
One who bears the earth in His womb; the support of the earth
Consort of Lakshmi; or one who is intoxicating like honey
The Slayer of the demon Madhu; destroyer of evil

lines.meaning: The Supreme Lord, the Valiant Bow-wielder, the Wise, the Courageous, the Cosmic Order

etymology.explanation: The Supreme Lord; one possessed of all divine powers
The Valiant One; famous for the three cosmic strides as Vamana
The Bow-wielder; one who carries the divine bow (Sharanga)
The Supremely Intelligent; endowed with perfect wisdom
Valor personified; the cosmic stride that measured the universe
The Cosmic Order; the systematic progression of all things

lines.meaning: The Unsurpassed, the Invincible, the Grateful, the Action itself, the Self-possessed
lines.note: Shloka 9 complete. These names highlight the supreme excellence, invincibility, and gratitude of the Divine.

etymology.explanation: The Unsurpassed; one than whom there is none higher
The Invincible; one who cannot be overcome by anyone
The Grateful; one who never forgets even the smallest act of devotion
Action itself; the doer and the deed combined
The Self-possessed; perfectly established in His own nature

lines.meaning: Lord of the Devas, the Refuge, Bliss, the Seed of the universe, the Source of all beings

etymology.explanation: Lord of the Devas; the supreme deity worshipped by all celestial beings
The Ultimate Refuge; the shelter for all who seek Him
Supreme Bliss; the ultimate state of happiness
The Seed of the universe; the cosmic cause of all creation
The Source from whom all creatures originate

lines.meaning: The Day, the Year, the Cosmic Serpent, the Trustworthy, the All-seeing
lines.note: Shloka 10 complete. This shloka emphasizes divine attributes related to time, trust, and omniscience.

etymology.explanation: The luminous Day; the light that dispels darkness
The Year; Time personified, in whom all creatures dwell
The Cosmic Serpent (Ananta/Shesha) on whom He reclines
The Trustworthy; one in whom all faith can be placed
The All-seeing; one who perceives everything past, present, and future

lines.meaning: The Unborn, Lord of all, the Accomplished, Accomplishment itself, the Origin of all, the Infallible

etymology.explanation: The Unborn; having no origin, existing eternally
Lord of all; the supreme controller of everything
The Accomplished; perfectly complete in all respects
Accomplishment itself; the ultimate goal and attainment
The Beginning of all; the primordial source of everything
The Infallible; one who never falls from His position or nature

lines.meaning: Vrishakapi (one who showers dharma), the Immeasurable Self, freed from all bondage
lines.note: Shloka 11 complete. This shloka features the unique name Vrishakapi and emphasizes the infinite, unbound nature of the Divine.

etymology.explanation: One who showers dharma like rain; or the boar (Varaha) who lifted the earth
One whose Self is immeasurable; infinitely vast in nature
One who is completely free from all material bondage; or the source of all yoga

lines.meaning: The Wealth, the Good-minded, the True, the Equal Self, the Well-measured, the Impartial

etymology.explanation: The Wealth; one in whom all treasures reside; the ultimate riches
The Good-minded; one whose mind is ever benevolent towards devotees
Truth itself; one who is eternally true and real
The Equal Self; equally present in all beings without distinction
The Well-proportioned; perfectly balanced in all His forms and actions
The Impartial; treating all beings with perfect equanimity

lines.meaning: The Unfailing, the Lotus-eyed (Pundarikaksha), the Doer of righteous deeds, the Embodiment of dharma
lines.note: Shloka 12 complete. This shloka features the beloved name Pundarikaksha (Lotus-eyed) and emphasizes dharmic qualities.

etymology.explanation: The Unfailing; whose grace and efforts never go in vain
The Lotus-eyed; whose beautiful eyes resemble lotus petals
One whose actions are always righteous; the doer of dharmic deeds
The Embodiment of dharma; whose very form represents righteousness

lines.meaning: The Fierce Destroyer, the Many-headed, the Supporter, the Source of the universe, the One of pure fame
lines.note: Shloka 13 begins. Rudra here refers to Vishnu's fierce aspect that dissolves evil. Vishvayoni establishes Him as the material cause of creation.

etymology.explanation: One who makes the wicked weep; also one who dispels sorrow (ru = sorrow, dra = destroyer)
The Many-headed; referring to His cosmic form with countless heads as described in the Purusha Sukta
The Supporter; one who bears and sustains the entire universe; also golden-brown colored (like honey)
The Source of the universe; the cosmic womb from which all creation emerges
One whose fame is pure; or one who is pleased by pure words of devotion; hearing about whom purifies

lines.meaning: The Immortal, the Eternally Firm, the Most Exalted, the Great Ascetic
lines.note: Shloka 13 complete. These names emphasize the Lord's eternal, unchanging nature and His supreme spiritual power.

etymology.explanation: The Immortal; one who is beyond death; also the nectar of immortality itself
The Eternally Firm; unchanging like a pillar through all cosmic cycles
The Most Exalted; one whose stature is supreme; or one who is the best vehicle for liberation
The Great Ascetic; one of supreme austerity; or one whose spiritual radiance (tapas) is immense

lines.meaning: The All-pervading, the All-knowing, the Radiant Sun, the Commander of all armies, the Liberator of people
lines.note: Shloka 14 begins. Janardana is one of the most beloved names, often interpreted as both 'one whom people worship' and 'one who destroys the wicked.'

etymology.explanation: The All-pervading; one who reaches everywhere; present in all beings and places
The All-knowing; omniscient one who knows everything—past, present, and future
The Radiant One; the Sun; one who illuminates all with the light of knowledge
One whose armies face all directions; the supreme commander whose forces protect the universe
One who is worshipped by people; or one who punishes the wicked; liberator of devotees

lines.meaning: The Veda itself, the Knower of Vedas, the Complete One, the Embodiment of Vedangas, the Wise Seer who knows the Vedas
lines.note: Shloka 14 complete. This shloka emphasizes the Lord's intimate connection with the Vedas—He is their source, their knower, and their very embodiment.

etymology.explanation: The Veda itself; the embodiment of all sacred knowledge; the source of the Vedas
The Knower of the Vedas; one who perfectly understands the true meaning of all scriptures
The Complete One; one with no deficiency; perfect in all aspects and limbs
The Embodiment of Vedangas; one whose limbs are the six auxiliary sciences of the Vedas
The Wise Seer who knows the Vedas; the omniscient poet who composed and knows all scripture

lines.meaning: The Overseer of worlds, the Lord of the gods, the Supervisor of dharma, the Cause of both cause and effect
lines.note: Shloka 15 begins. The three 'adhyaksha' names establish the Lord's supreme oversight over all realms, beings, and cosmic law.

etymology.explanation: The Overseer of all worlds; the supreme witness and ruler of all realms
The Lord of the gods; the supreme deity whom even the devas worship
The Supervisor of dharma; who ensures cosmic order and righteousness prevail
Both the effect and the cause; the manifested and the unmanifested; present in all states of existence

lines.meaning: The Fourfold Self, the Four Emanations, the Four-tusked (Varaha), the Four-armed
lines.note: Shloka 15 complete. The 'chatur' (four) names highlight the Lord's fourfold manifestations in philosophy (vyuha), incarnation (Varaha), and iconography (four arms).

etymology.explanation: The Fourfold Self; manifesting as mind (manas), intellect (buddhi), ego (ahaṅkāra), and consciousness (chitta)
The Four Emanations; manifesting as Vasudeva, Sankarshana, Pradyumna, and Aniruddha in Pancharatra philosophy
The Four-tusked; referring to His Varaha (boar) incarnation with four great tusks
The Four-armed; His iconic form holding conch, discus, mace, and lotus

lines.meaning: The Effulgent, the Food, the Enjoyer, the Forbearing, the First-born of the universe
lines.note: Shloka 16 begins. Bhojana and Bhokta reveal the Lord as both the sustenance and the one who experiences all—the object and subject of existence.

etymology.explanation: The Effulgent One; one who shines brilliantly; whose splendor illuminates all
The Food; that which nourishes all beings; the sustenance of the universe
The Enjoyer; the ultimate experiencer of all; the supreme consciousness that witnesses all
The Forbearing; one who patiently endures all; infinitely patient with the faults of devotees
Born at the beginning of the world; the primordial being from whom creation emanates

lines.meaning: The Sinless, the Victorious, the Conqueror, the Womb of the universe, the One who dwells again (in all)
lines.note: Shloka 16 complete. Vishvayoni appears again (also name 118), emphasizing the Lord as the material cause of creation. Punarvasu hints at His repeated incarnations.

etymology.explanation: The Sinless; completely free from sin or impurity; the absolutely pure one
The Victorious; one who triumphs in all endeavors; whose victory is certain
The Conqueror; who vanquishes all enemies and obstacles; the supreme victor
The Womb of the universe; the source from which all creation emerges (repeated for emphasis)
One who dwells again and again; who incarnates repeatedly for the welfare of the world

lines.meaning: The Younger brother of Indra, the Dwarf (Vamana), the Tall One, the Unfailing, the Pure, the Powerful
lines.note: Shloka 17 begins. Features the famous Vamana avatara—the dwarf who became Trivikrama. Upendra and Vamana both refer to this incarnation.

etymology.explanation: The Younger brother of Indra; born as Aditi's son after Indra; also 'superior to Indra'
The Dwarf; the fifth avatara who approached Bali as a small brahmana boy
The Tall One; who grew to cosmic proportions as Trivikrama; or one of radiant rays
The Unfailing; whose efforts and blessings never go in vain (repeated, also name 111)
The Pure One; untouched by any impurity; radiantly clean
The Powerful; possessing immense strength and vigor; supremely energetic

lines.deva: अतीन्द्रः सङ्ग्रहः सर्गो धृतात्मा नियमो यमः ॥
lines.iast: atīndraḥ saṅgrahaḥ sargō dhṛtātmā niyamō yamaḥ ॥
lines.knda: ಅತೀಂದ್ರಃ ಸಂಗ್ರಹಃ ಸರ್ಗೋ ಧೃತಾತ್ಮಾ ನಿಯಮೋ ಯಮಃ ॥
lines.tel: అతీంద్రః సంగ్రహః సర్గో ధృతాత్మా నియమో యమః ॥
lines.tam: அதீந்த்³ர: ஸங்க்³ரஹ: ஸர்கோ³ த்⁴ருதாத்மா நியமோ யம: ॥
lines.guj: અતીંદ્રઃ સંગ્રહઃ સર્ગો ધૃતાત્મા નિયમો યમઃ ॥
lines.pan: ਅਤੀਂਦ੍ਰਃ ਸਂਗ੍ਰਹਃ ਸਰ੍ਗੋ ਧ੍ਰੁਰੁਇਤਾਤ੍ਮਾ ਨਿਯਮੋ ਯਮਃ ॥
lines.mr: अतींद्रः संग्रहः सर्गो धृतात्मा नियमो यमः ॥
lines.meaning: Beyond Indra, the Gatherer, the Creation, the Self-sustained, the Regulator, the Controller
lines.note: Shloka 17 complete. Niyama and Yama together emphasize the Lord as the source of all cosmic order and moral law.

etymology.explanation: Beyond Indra; superior to the king of gods; transcending all celestial powers
The Gatherer; who collects and sustains all beings; the one who draws devotees to Himself
The Creation itself; or the creative power; the act and result of cosmic emanation
The Self-sustained; who holds Himself by His own power; needing no external support
The Regulator; who establishes cosmic laws and disciplines; the principle of order
The Controller; who restrains all; the inner controller of all beings and forces

lines.deva: वेद्यो वैद्यः सदायोगी वीरहा माधवो मधुः ।
lines.iast: vēdyō vaidyaḥ sadāyōgī vīrahā mādhavō madhuḥ ।
lines.knda: ವೇದ್ಯೋ ವೈದ್ಯಃ ಸದಾಯೋಗೀ ವೀರಹಾ ಮಾಧವೋ ಮಧುಃ ।
lines.tel: వేద్యో వైద్యః సదాయోగీ వీరహా మాధవో మధుః ।
lines.tam: வேத்³யோ வைத்³ய: ஸதா³யோகீ³ வீரஹா மாத⁴வோ மது⁴: ।
lines.guj: વેદ્યો વૈદ્યઃ સદાયોગી વીરહા માધવો મધુઃ ।
lines.pan: ਵੇਦ੍ਯੋ ਵੈਦ੍ਯਃ ਸਦਾਯੋਗੀ ਵੀਰਹਾ ਮਾਧਵੋ ਮਧੁਃ ।
lines.mr: वेद्यो वैद्यः सदायोगी वीरहा माधवो मधुः ।
lines.meaning: The Knowable, the Physician, the Eternal Yogi, the Slayer of heroes, Madhava (consort of Lakshmi), Sweet as honey
lines.note: Shloka 18 begins. Madhava is one of the most beloved names—Lord of Lakshmi, spring personified, and sweet like honey.

etymology.explanation: The Knowable; that which is to be known; the ultimate object of all knowledge and inquiry
The Physician; the supreme healer who cures the disease of saṃsāra (worldly existence)
The Eternal Yogi; ever united with His own nature; perpetually in the state of yoga
The Slayer of heroes; who destroys powerful demons and enemies of dharma
The Consort of Lakshmi (Mā); or descendant of Madhu; associated with spring season
Sweet as Honey; whose nature is infinitely sweet; the essence of bliss

lines.ben: বেদ্য়ো বৈদ্য়ঃ সদায়োগী বীরহা মাধবো মধুঃ ।
lines.mal: വേദ്യോ വൈദ്യഃ സദായോഗീ വീരഹാ മാധവോ മധുഃ ।
lines.meaning: Beyond the senses, the Great Illusionist, of Great enthusiasm, of Great strength
lines.note: Shloka 18 complete. The 'mahā' (great) names emphasize the Lord's supreme and infinite attributes—maya, enthusiasm, and strength.

etymology.explanation: Beyond the senses; who cannot be perceived by ordinary senses; transcending sensory experience
The Great Illusionist; wielder of the supreme cosmic illusion; master of divine magic
Of Great Enthusiasm; whose energy for creation and protection is boundless
Of Great Strength; possessing infinite power; the source of all strength in the universe

lines.meaning: Of Great Intelligence, of Great Valor, of Great Power, and of Great Radiance

etymology.explanation: Of Supreme Intelligence; possessing infinite wisdom that comprehends all
Of Great Valor; possessing supreme heroic energy that is inexhaustible
Of Great Power; the source of all cosmic energy and divine potency
Of Great Radiance; whose brilliance illuminates all worlds and dispels darkness

lines.meaning: Of Indescribable Form, the Lord of Shri (Lakshmi), of Immeasurable Self, and the Upholder of the Great Mountain
lines.note: Shloka 19 first half. These names continue the 'mahā' (great) series and introduce the Govardhana-dhāri form of Krishna.

etymology.explanation: Of Indescribable Form; whose divine body transcends all description and definition
The Possessor of Shri; the eternal consort of Lakshmi; endowed with all auspiciousness
Of Immeasurable Self; whose nature cannot be measured or limited by any means
The Upholder of the Great Mountain; lifted Govardhana to protect devotees from Indra's wrath

lines.meaning: The Wielder of the Great Bow, the Supporter of the Earth, the Abode of Shri, and the Refuge of the Virtuous

etymology.explanation: The Wielder of the Great Bow; as Rama, he wielded the mighty Sharnga bow with supreme skill
The Supporter of the Earth; bears the earth as Varaha (boar incarnation) and as Kurma (tortoise)
The Abode of Shri (Lakshmi); in whose heart Lakshmi eternally resides; famous Tirupati deity name
The Refuge of the Virtuous; the ultimate destination and support of all righteous souls

lines.meaning: The Unobstructed One, the Bliss of the Devas, the Finder of Cows/Knowledge, and the Lord of the Knowers
lines.note: Shloka 19 complete. Introduces the famous name Govinda with its multiple meanings, and Aniruddha of the Vyuha doctrine.

etymology.explanation: The Unobstructed One; whom nothing can impede; also Krishna's grandson and one of the Vyuha forms
The Bliss of the Devas; one who gives supreme joy to the celestial beings
The Finder of Cows; protector of cows in Vrindavan; also one who gives knowledge (go=veda); retrieved earth as Varaha
The Lord of the Knowers; master of those who have realized the Vedic wisdom

lines.meaning: The Ray of Light, the Subduer, the Swan, the Beautiful-Winged One, and the Best of Serpents

etymology.explanation: The Ray of Light; the subtle light particle; also name of a prajapati born from Brahma's mind
The Subduer; who subdues the wicked and controls all beings; master of dama (self-control)
The Swan; symbol of discrimination between real and unreal (separates milk from water); the divine syllable (ahaṃ saḥ = I am He)
The Beautiful-Winged One; as Garuda, the divine eagle; also refers to the Vedas as his wings
The Best of Serpents; as Ananta-Shesha upon whom the Lord reclines; lord of all nagas

lines.meaning: The Golden-Naveled One, the Great Ascetic, the Lotus-Naveled One, and the Lord of All Beings
lines.note: Shloka 20 complete. Features the iconic Padmanabha form and cosmic imagery of creation from the divine navel.

etymology.explanation: The Golden-Naveled One; from whose golden navel emerged the lotus of creation
The Great Ascetic; whose tapas (creative heat) manifests the universe; also performed tapas in human forms
The Lotus-Naveled One; from whose navel the cosmic lotus emerged bearing Brahma; the famous Thiruvananthapuram deity
The Lord of All Beings; the protector and sustainer of all created beings; progenitor of all

lines.deva: अमृत्युः सर्वदृक् सिंहः सन्धाता सन्धिमान् स्थिरः ।
lines.iast: amṛtyuḥ sarvadṛk siṃhaḥ sandhātā sandhimān sthiraḥ ।
lines.knda: ಅಮೃತ್ಯುಃ ಸರ್ವದೃಕ್ ಸಿಂಹಃ ಸಂಧಾತಾ ಸಂಧಿಮಾನ್ ಸ್ಥಿರಃ ।
lines.tel: అమృత్యుః సర్వదృక్ సింహః సంధాతా సంధిమాన్ స్థిరః ।
lines.tam: அம்ருத்யு: ஸர்வத்³ருக் ஸிம்ஹ: ஸந்தா⁴தா ஸந்தி⁴மான் ஸ்தி²ர: ।
lines.guj: અમૃત્યુઃ સર્વદૃક્ સિંહઃ સંધાતા સંધિમાન્ સ્થિરઃ ।
lines.pan: ਅਮ੍ਰੁਰੁਇਤ੍ਯੁਃ ਸਰ੍ਵਦ੍ਰੁਰੁਇਕ੍ ਸਿਂਹਃ ਸਂਧਾਤਾ ਸਂਧਿਮਾਨ੍ ਸ੍ਥਿਰਃ ।
lines.mr: अमृत्युः सर्वदृक् सिंहः संधाता संधिमान् स्थिरः ।
lines.meaning: The Deathless One, the All-Seeing, the Lion, the Unifier, the Connected One, and the Steadfast

etymology.explanation: The Deathless One; beyond mortality; one who has no death; grants immortality to devotees
The All-Seeing One; whose vision encompasses all beings, times, and places
The Lion; manifested as Narasimha (man-lion) to protect Prahlada; symbol of courage and sovereignty
The Unifier; who connects beings with their karmic fruits; brings together cause and effect
The Connected One; who possesses perfect union; in whom all connections exist
The Steadfast One; eternally unchanging; firmly established in his own nature

lines.ben: অমৃত্য়ুঃ সর্বদৃক্ সিংহঃ সংধাতা সংধিমান্ স্থিরঃ ।
lines.mal: അമൃത്യുഃ സർവദൃക് സിംഹഃ സംധാതാ സംധിമാന് സ്ഥിരഃ ।
lines.meaning: The Unborn, the Irresistible, the Ruler, the Famous-Souled One, and the Slayer of the Enemies of the Gods
lines.note: Shloka 21 complete. Features the iconic Narasimha reference (Simha) and emphasizes the Lord's protective nature.

etymology.explanation: The Unborn One; without origin; self-existent; also refers to a goat (symbolizing the Vedic sacrifice)
The Irresistible One; whom enemies cannot withstand; whose power is unbearable to the wicked
The Ruler/Teacher; who governs all through dharma; instructs through scriptures
The Famous-Souled One; whose glory is heard everywhere; celebrated in all the Vedas and Puranas
The Slayer of the Enemies of the Gods; destroyer of asuras who trouble the devas

lines.meaning: The Teacher, the Greatest of Teachers, the Abode, the Truth, and He of True Valor

etymology.explanation: The Teacher; the supreme preceptor who imparts knowledge; also heavy with divine qualities
The Greatest of Teachers; the supreme guru from whom all knowledge originates
The Abode; the supreme dwelling place; also light/brilliance; the ultimate destination
The Truth; who is the ultimate reality; ever truthful in word, thought, and deed
He of True Valor; whose heroism is always successful and righteous; never fails in his endeavors

lines.meaning: The Winking One, the Unwinking One, the Garlanded One, the Lord of Speech, and the Noble-Minded
lines.note: Shloka 22 complete. The pair nimisha/animisha beautifully captures the paradox of cosmic activity and eternal vigilance.

etymology.explanation: The Winking One; who closes his eyes in cosmic sleep (yoga-nidra); creator of time through the blink
The Unwinking One; ever vigilant; watches over all beings without a moment's inattention
The Garlanded One; adorned with the Vaijayanti garland of never-fading flowers
The Lord of Speech; master of all eloquence; from whom the Vedas emanated
The Noble-Minded One; of generous and exalted intelligence; benevolent in thought

lines.meaning: The Foremost Leader, the Village Chief, the Glorious, the Just, the Guide, and the Life-Breath

etymology.explanation: The Foremost Leader; who leads all beings; first among all
The Village Chief; leader of all beings collectively; chief of the cosmic community
The Glorious One; endowed with all divine wealth; the eternal consort of Lakshmi
The Just One; embodiment of righteousness and proper reasoning; dispenser of cosmic justice
The Guide; who leads all beings on the right path; the supreme navigator
The Life-Breath; as Vayu (wind), the vital force that animates all beings

lines.meaning: The Thousand-Headed, the Soul of the Universe, the Thousand-Eyed, and the Thousand-Footed
lines.note: Shloka 23 complete. The 'sahasra' (thousand) names echo the famous Purusha Sukta, describing the cosmic form.

etymology.explanation: The Thousand-Headed One; as the cosmic Purusha with innumerable heads; described in Purusha Sukta
The Soul of the Universe; the indwelling spirit of all creation; the cosmic self
The Thousand-Eyed One; who sees everything; infinite vision pervading all directions
The Thousand-Footed One; present everywhere; whose feet pervade all directions

lines.meaning: The Revolving One, the Withdrawn Self, the Concealed, and the Crusher

etymology.explanation: The Revolving One; who causes the wheel of samsara to turn; also one who returns as avatara
The Withdrawn Self; whose mind is turned away from worldly attachments; transcendent
The Concealed One; hidden by maya from ordinary perception; the mystery beyond comprehension
The Crusher; who completely destroys the enemies of dharma and the bondage of devotees

lines.meaning: The Day, the Dissolver, the Fire, the Wind, and the Bearer of the Earth
lines.note: Shloka 24 complete. Features the pancha-bhuta (five elements) aspects of the Lord - fire, wind, and earth.

etymology.explanation: The Day; the luminous one who dispels darkness; represents cosmic day of Brahma
The Dissolver; who brings about the cosmic dissolution (pralaya); also the pralaya fire/cloud
The Fire; who carries oblations to the gods; the cosmic fire principle; digestive fire in all beings
The Wind; the life-giving breath; the cosmic vital force (prana); also Vayu, father of Hanuman
The Bearer of the Earth; as Varaha, Kurma, or Shesha who supports the earth

lines.meaning: The Gracious One, the Serene-Souled, the Supporter of the Universe, the Enjoyer of the Universe, and the All-Pervading

etymology.explanation: The Gracious One; who bestows abundant grace; easily pleased and grants blessings
The Serene-Souled One; whose nature is pure tranquility; ever blissful
The Supporter of the Universe; who sustains all creation; the cosmic foundation
The Enjoyer/Protector of the Universe; who experiences all and protects all
The All-Pervading One; present everywhere; the Lord who exists in all

lines.meaning: The Doer of Good, the Well-Honored, the Saint, Jahnu, Narayana, and Nara
lines.note: Shloka 25 complete. Features the famous name Narayana and establishes the Nara-Narayana identity.

etymology.explanation: The Doer of Good; who creates and does only what is righteous and beneficial
The Well-Honored One; who is worshipped by all good people; rightly celebrated
The Saint; the embodiment of virtue; one who accomplishes the good of all beings
Jahnu; the sage who swallowed the Ganga and released her; signifies the Lord's control over sacred rivers
Narayana; the abode of all beings; who rests on the cosmic waters; the goal of all souls
Nara; the primeval man; the eternal companion of Narayana (Nara-Narayana rishi pair)

lines.meaning: The Innumerable, the Immeasurable Self, the Distinguished, the Creator of the Disciplined, and the Pure

etymology.explanation: The Innumerable One; whose forms, qualities, and glories cannot be counted
The Immeasurable Self; whose nature cannot be comprehended by any means of knowledge
The Distinguished One; who stands apart from all; uniquely excellent
The Creator of the Disciplined; who establishes righteous conduct; maker of the virtuous
The Pure One; absolutely untainted; whose purity purifies all who approach him

lines.meaning: The Fulfilled Goal, the Infallible Will, the Bestower of Accomplishment, and the Means to Perfection
lines.note: Shloka 26 complete. The 'siddhi' sequence emphasizes the Lord as both the goal and the means to spiritual perfection.

etymology.explanation: The Fulfilled Goal; whose purpose is ever accomplished; the complete object of attainment
The Infallible Will; whose every resolve is immediately fulfilled; satyasankalpa
The Bestower of Accomplishment; who grants all siddhis (spiritual powers) to devotees
The Means to Perfection; the path itself to spiritual attainment; both goal and way

lines.meaning: The Day of Dharma, the Bull of Dharma, the All-Pervading, the Dharma as Joints, and the Dharma-Bellied

etymology.explanation: The Day of Dharma; in whom righteousness shines like daylight; or who showers dharma
The Bull of Dharma; the excellent one; chief among all; showers blessings like rain
The All-Pervading One; who pervades the entire universe; the famous name from the Trivikrama form
He whose limbs/joints are dharma; dharma constitutes his very structure
The Dharma-Bellied One; whose abdomen contains all dharma; or who sustains dharma within

lines.meaning: The Nourisher, the Ever-Growing, the Distinct, and the Ocean of Vedas
lines.note: Shloka 27 complete. The 'vṛṣa' (dharma/bull) sequence emphasizes the Lord as the embodiment and support of dharma.

etymology.explanation: The Nourisher; who causes everything to grow and prosper; the cosmic nurturer
The Ever-Growing One; whose glory ever increases; or who grows within the hearts of devotees
The Distinct One; who is separate from all; pure and unmixed with anything material
The Ocean of Vedas; into whom all Vedic knowledge flows; the repository of all scripture

lines.deva: सुभुजो दुर्धरो वाग्मी महेन्द्रो वसुदो वसुः ।
lines.iast: subhujō durdharō vāgmī mahēndrō vasudō vasuḥ ।
lines.knda: ಸುಭುಜೋ ದುರ್ಧರೋ ವಾಗ್ಮೀ ಮಹೇಂದ್ರೋ ವಸುದೋ ವಸುಃ ।
