lines.tel: సుభుజో దుర్ధరో వాగ్మీ మహేంద్రో వసుదో వసుః ।
lines.tam: ஸுபு⁴ஜோ து³ர்த⁴ரோ வாக்³மீ மஹேந்த்³ரோ வஸுதோ³ வஸு: ।
lines.guj: સુભુજો દુર્ધરો વાગ્મી મહેંદ્રો વસુદો વસુઃ ।
lines.pan: ਸੁਭੁਜੋ ਦੁਰ੍ਧਰੋ ਵਾਗ੍ਮੀ ਮਹੇਂਦ੍ਰੋ ਵਸੁਦੋ ਵਸੁਃ ।
lines.mr: सुभुजो दुर्धरो वाग्मी महेंद्रो वसुदो वसुः ।
lines.meaning: The Beautiful-Armed, the Invincible, the Eloquent, the Great Indra, the Giver of Wealth, and the Treasure

etymology.explanation: The Beautiful-Armed One; whose arms are graceful and powerful; protector of devotees
The Invincible One; whom no one can overpower; difficult for enemies to withstand
The Eloquent One; master of speech; whose words are the Vedas themselves
The Great Indra; the supreme lord of all lords; greater than all the devas including Indra
The Giver of Wealth; who bestows all forms of prosperity upon devotees
The Treasure; who is the supreme wealth; who dwells in all beings

lines.ben: সুভুজো দুর্ধরো বাগ্মী মহেংদ্রো বসুদো বসুঃ ।
lines.mal: സുഭുജോ ദുര്ധരോ വാഗ്മീ മഹേംദ്രോ വസുദോ വസുഃ ।
lines.meaning: The Many-Formed, the Vast-Formed, the Pervading Light, and the Illuminator
lines.note: Shloka 28 complete. Features the cosmic light and form aspects, including the famous Vishvarupa concept.

etymology.explanation: The Many-Formed One; who assumes countless forms; manifests as many for the sake of creation
The Vast-Formed One; whose cosmic form encompasses all; the Vishvarupa
The Pervading Light; who pervades as rays of light; present in all beings as the inner light
The Illuminator; who reveals all things; makes knowledge and existence possible through his light

lines.meaning: The Bearer of Vitality-Brilliance-Splendor, the Luminous Self, and the Scorcher

etymology.explanation: The Bearer of Vitality, Brilliance, and Splendor; who holds all three forms of divine energy
The Luminous Self; whose very nature is pure consciousness-light; self-luminous
The Scorcher; who burns away sins and enemies; whose brilliance scorches the wicked

lines.meaning: The Prosperous, the Clear-Syllabled, the Sacred Formula, the Moon-Rayed, and the Sun-Brilliant
lines.note: Shloka 29 complete. The lunar and solar imagery shows the Lord as both cooling grace and scorching brilliance.

etymology.explanation: The Prosperous One; who is endowed with all abundance; supremely successful in all
The Clear-Syllabled One; whose teaching (Gita, Vedas) is clear and unmistakable
The Sacred Formula; who is the essence of all mantras; protects those who contemplate him
The Moon-Rayed One; whose presence is cooling like moonlight; source of soothing grace
The Sun-Brilliant One; whose radiance equals the sun; dispels the darkness of ignorance

lines.meaning: The Source of the Nectar-Rayed Moon, the Sun, the Moon-Marked, and the Lord of Devas

etymology.explanation: The Source of the Nectar-Rayed Moon; from whom the moon with its nectar-like rays emerged
The Sun; the self-luminous one; source of all light in the universe
The Moon-Marked One; the moon with the rabbit-shaped mark; or king Shashabindu
The Lord of Devas; the supreme ruler of all celestial beings

lines.meaning: The Medicine, the Bridge of the World, and He of Truth-Dharma-Valor
lines.note: Shloka 30 complete. The 'setu' (bridge) imagery is significant - dharma as the bridge to moksha.

etymology.explanation: The Medicine; the remedy for the disease of samsara; heals all afflictions of existence
The Bridge of the World; who serves as the means to cross the ocean of samsara; dharma as the bridge
He of Truth, Dharma, and Valor; whose heroism is founded in truth and righteousness; Rama's epithet

lines.meaning: The Lord of Past-Future-Present, the Wind, the Purifier, and the Fire

etymology.explanation: The Lord of Past, Future, and Present; master of all three times; transcends time itself
The Wind; the purifying vital breath; as Vayu, sustains all life
The Purifier; who cleanses all beings of their sins; remembrance alone purifies
The Fire; whose energy is never sufficient (infinite); the digestive fire in all beings

lines.meaning: The Slayer of Desires, the Desire-Fulfiller, the Lovely, the Desired, the Desire-Granter, and the Lord
lines.note: Shloka 31 complete. The 'kāma' (desire) sequence shows the Lord as both the destroyer of binding desires and fulfiller of righteous ones.

etymology.explanation: The Slayer of Desires; who destroys the bondage of worldly desires in devotees
The Desire-Fulfiller; who fulfills the righteous desires of devotees
The Lovely One; who is supremely beautiful and attractive; the beloved of all
The Desired One; who is the object of all desires; the supreme desideratum
The Desire-Granter; who bestows all that devotees desire, including liberation
The Lord; the master of all; supremely capable of all actions

lines.meaning: The Creator of Cosmic Ages, the Cycle of Ages, the Many-Maya, and the Great Eater

etymology.explanation: The Creator of Cosmic Ages; who initiates each yuga (Satya, Treta, Dvapara, Kali)
The Cycle of Ages; who causes the yugas to revolve in endless cycles
The Many-Maya; who possesses countless divine powers; manifests through many mayas
The Great Eater; who consumes all at pralaya; the cosmic devourer at dissolution

lines.meaning: The Invisible, the Manifest-Form, the Conqueror of Thousands, and the Infinite Victor
lines.note: Shloka 32 complete. The paradox of adṛśya (invisible) and vyaktarūpa (manifest) captures the divine mystery.

etymology.explanation: The Invisible One; who cannot be seen by ordinary vision; beyond sense perception
The Manifest-Form; who appears in visible forms as avatars for devotees
The Conqueror of Thousands; who vanquishes innumerable enemies; omnipotent
The Infinite Victor; whose victories are endless; ever unconquered

lines.meaning: The Desired, the Impartial, the Beloved of the Good, the Crest-Adorned, Nahusha, and Dharma

etymology.explanation: The Desired One; who is sought by all beings; the object of all worship
The Impartial One; who shows no partiality; equal to all beings
The Beloved of the Good; who is dear to the righteous and learned
The Crest-Adorned One; adorned with peacock feathers; also as the cosmic dancer
Nahusha; the binder of all beings through maya; or the famous king Nahusha
Dharma; the bull of dharma; showers blessings upon devotees

lines.meaning: The Anger-Slayer, the Righteous-Anger-Maker, the Cosmic-Armed, and the Mountain-Bearer
lines.note: Shloka 33 complete. The krodha (anger) pair shows the Lord both removes personal anger and inspires righteous indignation.

etymology.explanation: The Anger-Slayer; who destroys the anger of devotees; removes the affliction of wrath
The Righteous-Anger-Maker; who creates anger in devotees against adharma
The Doer; the supreme creator and actor; cause of all actions
The Cosmic-Armed One; whose arms pervade the universe; protects all directions
The Mountain-Bearer; who supports the earth; as mountains and as Varaha/Kurma

lines.meaning: The Infallible, the Famous, the Life-Breath, the Life-Giver, and Indra's Younger Brother

etymology.explanation: The Infallible One; who never falls from his nature; eternally steadfast; a beloved name of Krishna
The Famous One; whose glory is spread throughout all worlds; universally celebrated
The Life-Breath; the vital force that animates all beings; the cosmic prana
The Life-Giver; who bestows the vital breath upon all beings; grants liberation
Indra's Younger Brother; as Vamana, born after Indra from Aditi; the divine dwarf

lines.meaning: The Ocean Treasure, the Foundation, the Ever-Vigilant, and the Well-Established
lines.note: Shloka 34 complete. Features the famous name Achyuta, one of the most beloved names of Lord Krishna.

etymology.explanation: The Ocean Treasure; the repository of all waters; sleeps on the cosmic ocean
The Foundation; the substratum upon which all existence rests; the ultimate support
The Ever-Vigilant One; never careless or negligent; eternally watchful over all
The Well-Established One; firmly rooted in his own glory; the ultimate foundation

lines.meaning: The Leaper, the Skanda-Bearer, the Chief, the Boon-Granter, and the Wind-Vehicled

etymology.explanation: The Leaper; who leaps to protect devotees; also refers to Kartikeya (Skanda)
The Skanda-Bearer; father of Kartikeya; who supports and manifests as Skanda
The Chief; who bears the burden of the universe; the foremost leader
The Boon-Granter; who bestows blessings upon devotees; the generous Lord
The Wind-Vehicled One; who rides on Garuda swift as the wind; controls the wind

lines.meaning: Vasudeva, the Great Sun, the Primeval God, and the City-Destroyer
lines.note: Shloka 35 complete. Features the supremely sacred name Vasudeva - 'vāsudevaḥ sarvam iti' (Vasudeva is everything).

etymology.meaning: wealth/dwelling + god; or son of Vasudeva
etymology.explanation: Vasudeva; the Lord who dwells in all; also Krishna as son of Vasudeva; one of the most sacred names
The Great Sun; whose brilliance exceeds all luminaries; the supreme light
The Primeval God; the first deity; source of all other deities
The City-Destroyer; who destroys the fortresses of enemies; also an epithet of Indra

lines.meaning: The Sorrowless, the Deliverer, the Savior, the Hero, Shauri (Krishna), and the Lord of People

etymology.explanation: The Sorrowless One; free from all grief; removes the sorrow of devotees
The Deliverer; who enables beings to cross the ocean of samsara
The Savior; who rescues beings from all dangers and fears
The Hero; supremely valiant; performs heroic deeds effortlessly
Shauri; grandson of Shura (Vasudeva's father); a name of Krishna
The Lord of People; ruler of all beings; the supreme sovereign

lines.meaning: The Favorable, the Hundred-Whorled, the Lotus-Holder, and the Lotus-Eyed
lines.note: Shloka 36 complete. Features the beloved name Shauri (Krishna as descendant of Shura).

etymology.explanation: The Favorable One; who is well-disposed to all beings; supports their welfare
The Hundred-Whorled One; whose conch (Panchajanya) has a hundred whorls; cosmic spiral
The Lotus-Holder; who holds the lotus in hand; associated with purity and creation
The Lotus-Eyed; whose eyes are beautiful like lotus petals; captivating glance

lines.meaning: The Lotus-Naveled, the Lotus-Eyed, the Lotus-Wombed, and the Body-Sustainer

etymology.explanation: The Lotus-Naveled One; from whose navel the cosmic lotus with Brahma emerged; famous Thiruvananthapuram deity
The Lotus-Eyed; whose eyes are like beautiful lotus flowers; enchanting vision
The Lotus-Wombed; whose heart is pure like a lotus; or who resides in the cosmic lotus
The Body-Sustainer; who supports all bodies; the indwelling sustainer of all forms

lines.meaning: The Greatly Prosperous, the Flourished, the Ancient Self, the Great-Eyed, and the Garuda-Bannered
lines.note: Shloka 37 complete. The 'padma' (lotus) sequence emphasizes purity and divine beauty.

etymology.explanation: The Greatly Prosperous; endowed with supreme abundance; possesses all divine powers
The Flourished One; who has attained all success; complete in all aspects
The Ancient Self; the primordial soul; most venerable and wise being
The Great-Eyed; with large beautiful eyes; whose vision encompasses all
The Garuda-Bannered; whose flag bears Garuda; rides the divine eagle

lines.meaning: The Incomparable, the Sharabha, the Fearsome, the Knower of Time, and Hari the Oblation-Accepter

etymology.explanation: The Incomparable One; who has no equal; beyond all comparison
The Sharabha; a powerful mythical creature; represents supreme strength
The Fearsome One; who inspires awe and fear in the wicked; terrifying to evil
The Knower of Time; who knows the right time for everything; keeper of cosmic order
Hari the Oblation-Accepter; who receives all sacrificial offerings; the ultimate recipient

lines.meaning: The One Known by All Marks, the Possessor of Lakshmi, and the Victor in Battle
lines.note: Shloka 38 complete. Features Lakshmi and auspicious marks, central to Vaishnavism.

etymology.explanation: The One Known by All Auspicious Marks; bears all signs of divinity; recognized by sacred attributes
The Possessor of Lakshmi; eternally accompanied by the goddess of fortune
The Victor in Battle; who conquers in all assemblies and conflicts; ever triumphant

lines.meaning: The Imperishable, the Red One, the Path, the Cause, Damodara, and the Enduring

etymology.explanation: The Imperishable; who never decays; eternally indestructible
The Red One; of beautiful red complexion; or the cosmic fish (Matsya) avatar
The Path; the way to liberation; the dharmic path to be followed
The Cause; the ultimate reason for all existence; the first cause
Damodara; who was bound by a rope around the belly by Yashoda; beloved name of child Krishna
The Enduring One; who bears all; patient and all-tolerating

lines.meaning: The Earth-Bearer, the Greatly Fortunate, the Swift, and the Infinite Consumer
lines.note: Shloka 39 complete. Features the beloved name Damodara - the child Krishna bound with a rope.

etymology.explanation: The Earth-Bearer; who supports the earth as Varaha, Kurma, and mountains
The Greatly Fortunate; who possesses supreme fortune; or whose devotees are most fortunate
The Swift One; who acts with supreme speed; reaches devotees instantly
The Infinite Consumer; who consumes infinitely at pralaya; also as Agni consuming oblations

lines.meaning: The Source, the Agitator, the Deity, the Womb of Shri, and the Supreme Lord

etymology.explanation: The Source; the origin of all; from whom everything emerges
The Agitator; who disturbs prakrti to initiate creation; stirs the cosmic waters
The Deity; the self-luminous one; who sports in divine play (lila)
The Womb of Shri; in whom Lakshmi resides; source of all auspiciousness
The Supreme Lord; the ultimate controller; lord of all lords

lines.deva: करणं कारणं कर्ता विकर्ता गहनो गुहः ॥
lines.iast: karaṇaṃ kāraṇaṃ kartā vikartā gahanō guhaḥ ॥
lines.knda: ಕರಣಂ ಕಾರಣಂ ಕರ್ತಾ ವಿಕರ್ತಾ ಗಹನೋ ಗುಹಃ ॥
lines.tel: కరణం కారణం కర్తా వికర్తా గహనో గుహః ॥
lines.tam: கரணம் காரணம் கர்தா விகர்தா க³ஹனோ கு³ஹ: ॥
lines.guj: કરણં કારણં કર્તા વિકર્તા ગહનો ગુહઃ ॥
lines.pan: ਕਰਣਂ ਕਾਰਣਂ ਕਰ੍ਤਾ ਵਿਕਰ੍ਤਾ ਗਹਨੋ ਗੁਹਃ ॥
lines.mr: करणं कारणं कर्ता विकर्ता गहनो गुहः ॥
lines.meaning: The Instrument, the Cause, the Creator, the Transformer, the Inscrutable, and the Cave-Dweller
lines.note: Shloka 40 complete. Features the profound philosophical terms karana (instrument), karana (cause), and karta (doer).

etymology.explanation: The Instrument; the means by which all is accomplished; cosmic instrument of creation
The Cause; the ultimate cause of all effects; the first cause
The Creator; the doer of all actions; the cosmic agent
The Transformer; who creates diverse forms; modifies and transforms creation
The Inscrutable One; whose nature is profound and unfathomable; beyond comprehension
The Cave-Dweller; who dwells in the cave of the heart; the hidden inner self

lines.meaning: The Resolute Effort, the Ordainer, the Foundation, the Place-Giver, and the Immovable
lines.note: Shloka 41 first half.

etymology.explanation: The Resolute Effort; who is the source of all determination; inspires focused action
The Ordainer; who establishes cosmic order; arranges all things properly
The Foundation; the ultimate abode where all rests; the cosmic foundation
The Place-Giver; who grants appropriate positions to all; bestows stations according to karma
The Immovable One; eternally fixed; like the pole star; the unchanging center

lines.meaning: The Supremely Prosperous, the Clearly Manifest, the Contented, the Nourished, and the Auspicious-Eyed
lines.note: Shloka 41 complete.

etymology.explanation: The Supremely Prosperous; possessing the highest abundance; ultimate wealth
The Clearly Manifest; whose reality is supremely evident; self-evident truth
The Contented One; ever satisfied; complete in himself requiring nothing
The Nourished One; full and complete; also nourishes all beings
The Auspicious-Eyed; whose glance bestows blessings; benevolent vision

lines.meaning: Rama, the Resting Place, the Passionless, the Path-Guide, the Wise, and the Ruler of the Unruly

etymology.explanation: Rama; the delightful one; one in whom all rejoice; the avatar prince of Ayodhya
The Resting Place; in whom all activities cease at pralaya; the final rest
The Passionless One; free from rajas; pure and untainted
The Path; the way to liberation; to be followed by seekers
The Guide; to whom one should surrender for guidance; the supreme leader
The Wise One; embodiment of wisdom and right conduct; the nīti

etymology.meaning: who cannot be led/ruler of unruly
etymology.explanation: The Ruler of the Unruly; who controls those without discipline; or who has no superior guide

lines.meaning: The Hero, the Best among the Powerful, Dharma Itself, and the Best Knower of Dharma
lines.note: Shloka 42 complete.

etymology.explanation: The Hero; supremely valorous; one who conquers all enemies
The Best among the Powerful; supreme among all who possess strength
Dharma Itself; the cosmic order; righteousness personified
The Best Knower of Dharma; supreme authority on righteousness

lines.deva: वैकुण्ठः पुरुषः प्राणः प्राणदः प्रणवः पृथुः ।
lines.iast: vaikuṇṭhaḥ puruṣaḥ prāṇaḥ prāṇadaḥ praṇavaḥ pṛthuḥ ।
lines.knda: ವೈಕುಂಠಃ ಪುರುಷಃ ಪ್ರಾಣಃ ಪ್ರಾಣದಃ ಪ್ರಣವಃ ಪೃಥುಃ ।
lines.tel: వైకుంఠః పురుషః ప్రాణః ప్రాణదః ప్రణవః పృథుః ।
lines.tam: வைகுண்ட:² புருஷ: ப்ராண: ப்ராணத:³ ப்ரணவ: ப்ருது²: ।
lines.guj: વૈકુંઠઃ પુરુષઃ પ્રાણઃ પ્રાણદઃ પ્રણવઃ પૃથુઃ ।
lines.pan: ਵੈਕੁਂਠਃ ਪੁਰੁਸ਼ਃ ਪ੍ਰਾਣਃ ਪ੍ਰਾਣਦਃ ਪ੍ਰਣਵਃ ਪ੍ਰੁਰੁਇਥੁਃ ।
lines.mr: वैकुंठः पुरुषः प्राणः प्राणदः प्रणवः पृथुः ।
lines.meaning: Lord of Vaikuntha, the Purusha, Life Force, Giver of Life, the Pranava (Om), and the Expansive One
lines.note: Shloka 43 first half. Features Vaikuntha and Pranava (Om).

etymology.explanation: Lord of Vaikuntha; one who removes obstacles; presides over the supreme abode
The Purusha; the cosmic person; indweller of all bodies; primal being
The Life Force; vital breath; the animating principle of all beings
Giver of Life; who bestows the vital breath to all; source of animation
The Pranava; the sacred syllable Om; supreme sound; praised by all Vedas
The Expansive One; vast and wide; also King Prithu avatar

lines.ben: বৈকুংঠঃ পুরুষঃ প্রাণঃ প্রাণদঃ প্রণবঃ পৃথুঃ ।
lines.mal: വൈകുംഠഃ പുരുഷഃ പ്രാണഃ പ്രാണദഃ പ്രണവഃ പൃഥുഃ ।
lines.meaning: The Golden Womb, Slayer of Enemies, the All-Pervading, the Wind, and Beyond Sense Perception
lines.note: Shloka 43 complete.

etymology.explanation: The Golden Womb; cosmic egg; Brahma the creator emerged from him
Slayer of Enemies; destroys the foes of devotees; annihilator of asuras
The All-Pervading; present everywhere; nothing exists outside him
The Wind; subtle life-giving air; inner controller of Vayu
Beyond Sense Perception; transcends the grasp of senses; imperceptible to material faculties

lines.meaning: The Season, the Beautiful to Behold, Time, the Supreme Lord, and the Receiver
lines.note: Shloka 44 first half.

etymology.explanation: The Season; cosmic cycles; the proper time for everything
Beautiful to Behold; pleasing vision; also the divine discus Sudarshana
Time; the great destroyer; who measures and ends all
The Supreme Lord; who stands in the highest position; supreme station
The Receiver; accepts offerings of devotees; encompasses all

lines.meaning: The Fierce, the Year, the Skilful, the Resting Place, and the Most Generous to All
lines.note: Shloka 44 complete.

etymology.explanation: The Fierce One; terrible to the wicked; inspires awe
The Year; in whom all beings dwell; the cosmic cycle of time
The Skilful One; dexterous and capable; performs all acts with expertise
The Resting Place; where all beings find rest; ultimate peace
Most Generous to All; gives liberally to the entire universe; supremely skilful

lines.meaning: The Expansion, the Stable, the Pillar, the Standard of Proof, and the Imperishable Seed
lines.note: Shloka 45 first half.

etymology.explanation: The Expansion; pervades and extends throughout creation
The Stable One; immovable; steadfast reality
The Pillar; firm and unchanging support; ever stationary
The Standard of Proof; ultimate authority; means of valid knowledge
The Imperishable Seed; eternal cause of creation; indestructible source

lines.meaning: The Goal, Beyond Need, the Great Treasury, the Great Enjoyer, and the Greatly Wealthy
lines.note: Shloka 45 complete.

etymology.explanation: The Goal; ultimate purpose sought by all; wealth and meaning
Beyond Need; who lacks nothing; self-sufficient
The Great Treasury; storehouse of infinite wealth; cosmic repository
The Great Enjoyer; experiences supreme bliss; bestows enjoyments
The Greatly Wealthy; possessor of supreme riches; source of all prosperity

lines.meaning: The Never Dejected, the Largest, the Earth/Existence, the Pillar of Dharma, and the Great Sacrifice
lines.note: Shloka 46 first half.

etymology.explanation: The Never Dejected; free from weariness; tireless in sustaining creation
The Largest; most massive; supremely stable; greatest in magnitude
The Earth; existence itself; foundation of all; the ground of being
Pillar of Dharma; the sacrificial post of righteousness; support of cosmic order
The Great Sacrifice; supreme yajña; the goal and performer of all rituals

lines.meaning: The Axis of Stars, Lord of Stars, the Patient, the Subtle, and the Doer
lines.note: Shloka 46 complete.

etymology.explanation: Axis of the Stars; around whom the constellations revolve; cosmic center
Lord of Stars; the moon (nakṣatreśa); ruler of the stellar realm
The Patient One; supremely forbearing; forgives all offenses
The Subtle One; reduced to essence; transcends material form
The Doer; who strives for the welfare of beings; actively engaged

lines.deva: यज्ञ इज्यो महेज्यश्च क्रतुः सत्रं सताङ्गतिः ।
lines.iast: yajña ijyō mahējyaścha kratuḥ satraṃ satāṅgatiḥ ।
lines.knda: ಯಜ್ಞ ಇಜ್ಯೋ ಮಹೇಜ್ಯಶ್ಚ ಕ್ರತುಃ ಸತ್ರಂ ಸತಾಂಗತಿಃ ।
lines.tel: యజ్ఞ ఇజ్యో మహేజ్యశ్చ క్రతుః సత్రం సతాంగతిః ।
lines.tam: யஜ்ஞ இஜ்யோ மஹேஜ்யஶ்ச க்ரது: ஸத்ரம் ஸதாங்க³தி: ।
lines.guj: યજ્ઞ ઇજ્યો મહેજ્યશ્ચ ક્રતુઃ સત્રં સતાંગતિઃ ।
lines.pan: ਯਜ੍ਞ ਇਜ੍ਯੋ ਮਹੇਜ੍ਯਸ਼੍ਚ ਕ੍ਰਤੁਃ ਸਤ੍ਰਂ ਸਤਾਂਗਤਿਃ ।
lines.mr: यज्ञ इज्यो महेज्यश्च क्रतुः सत्रं सतांगतिः ।
lines.meaning: The Sacrifice, the Worshipped, the Greatly Worshipped, the Ritual, the Extended Sacrifice, and Refuge of the Good
lines.note: Shloka 47 first half.

etymology.explanation: The Sacrifice; embodiment of all yajñas; Vishnu is yajña personified
The Worshipped One; fit to be adored through sacrifice
The Greatly Worshipped; supreme object of worship; most worthy of adoration
The Ritual; the will to perform; sacred ceremony personified
The Sattra; prolonged sacrifice; protector of the good
Refuge of the Good; destination of the righteous; shelter for devotees

lines.ben: যজ্ঞ ইজ্য়ো মহেজ্যশ্চ ক্রতুঃ সত্রং সতাংগতিঃ ।
lines.mal: യജ്ഞ ഇജ്യോ മഹേജ്യശ്ച ക്രതുഃ സത്രം സതാംഗതിഃ ।
lines.meaning: The All-Seeing, the Liberated Self, the All-Knowing, and the Supreme Knowledge
lines.note: Shloka 47 complete.

etymology.explanation: The All-Seeing; witnesses everything; omniscient perceiver
The Liberated Self; eternally free; never bound by māyā
The All-Knowing; omniscient; knows past, present, and future
The Supreme Knowledge; highest wisdom; ultimate truth itself

lines.deva: सुव्रतः सुमुखः सूक्ष्मः सुघोषः सुखदः सुहृत् ।
lines.iast: suvrataḥ sumukhaḥ sūkṣmaḥ sughōṣaḥ sukhadaḥ suhṛt ।
lines.knda: ಸುವ್ರತಃ ಸುಮುಖಃ ಸೂಕ್ಷ್ಮಃ ಸುಘೋಷಃ ಸುಖದಃ ಸುಹೃತ್ ।
lines.tel: సువ్రతః సుముఖః సూక్ష్మః సుఘోషః సుఖదః సుహృత్ ।
lines.tam: ஸுவ்ரத: ஸுமுக:² ஸூக்ஷ்ம: ஸுகோ⁴ஷ: ஸுக²த:³ ஸுஹ்ருத் ।
lines.guj: સુવ્રતઃ સુમુખઃ સૂક્ષ્મઃ સુઘોષઃ સુખદઃ સુહૃત્ ।
lines.pan: ਸੁਵ੍ਰਤਃ ਸੁਮੁਖਃ ਸੂਕ੍ਸ਼੍ਮਃ ਸੁਘੋਸ਼ਃ ਸੁਖਦਃ ਸੁਹ੍ਰੁਰੁਇਤ੍ ।
lines.mr: सुव्रतः सुमुखः सूक्ष्मः सुघोषः सुखदः सुहृत् ।
lines.meaning: Of Excellent Vows, Beautiful-Faced, the Subtle, Sweet-Voiced, Giver of Happiness, and the True Friend
lines.note: Shloka 48 first half.

etymology.explanation: Of Excellent Vows; whose resolutions are noble; keeps sacred observances
Beautiful-Faced; of pleasing countenance; gracious expression
The Subtle One; beyond gross perception; imperceptible essence
Sweet-Voiced; of melodious proclamation; whose fame resounds beautifully
Giver of Happiness; bestows bliss to devotees; source of joy
The True Friend; well-wisher of all; compassionate heart

lines.ben: সুব্রতঃ সুমুখঃ সূক্ষ্মঃ সুঘোষঃ সুখদঃ সুহৃত্ ।
lines.mal: സുവ്രതഃ സുമുഖഃ സൂക്ഷ്മഃ സുഘോഷഃ സുഖദഃ സുഹൃത് ।
lines.meaning: The Mind-Captivating, Conqueror of Anger, Heroic-Armed, and the Tearer of Enemies
lines.note: Shloka 48 complete.

etymology.explanation: The Mind-Captivating; steals the hearts of devotees; enchanting
Conqueror of Anger; master over wrath; supremely self-controlled
Heroic-Armed; with mighty arms; valorous limbs
The Tearer; rends asunder enemies of dharma; Narasimha tearing Hiranyakashipu

lines.meaning: Who Puts to Sleep, Self-Controlled, All-Pervading, of Many Forms, and Performer of Many Actions
lines.note: Shloka 49 first half.

etymology.explanation: Who Puts to Sleep; causes cosmic dissolution; withdraws beings into rest
Self-Controlled; under his own power; independent
The All-Pervading; fills all space and time; omnipresent
Of Many Forms; manifests as countless beings; diverse embodiments
Performer of Many Actions; does countless deeds; infinite activities

lines.meaning: The Abode, the Affectionate, Father-Protector, Jewel-Womb, and Lord of Wealth
lines.note: Shloka 49 complete.

etymology.explanation: The Abode; in whom all dwell; also the year (time cycle)
The Affectionate; tender love for devotees; like a cow for her calf
Father-Protector; has devotees as calves; nurturing guardian
Jewel-Womb; contains all precious things; ocean of gems
Lord of Wealth; master of all riches; bestower of prosperity

lines.meaning: Protector of Dharma, Creator of Dharma, the Righteous, Being and Non-Being, the Perishable and Imperishable
lines.note: Shloka 50 first half. Deep philosophical names: Sat-Asat, Kshara-Akshara pairs.

etymology.explanation: Protector of Dharma; guards righteousness; shields cosmic order
Creator of Dharma; establishes righteousness; author of cosmic law
The Righteous; embodiment of dharma; supremely virtuous
Being; pure existence; the real; truth itself
Non-Being; beyond manifest existence; transcends categories
The Perishable; the changing creation; transient forms
The Imperishable; unchanging reality; eternal truth

lines.meaning: The Unknowable, Thousand-Rayed, the Creator, and Who Has Distinguished Marks
lines.note: Shloka 50 complete.

etymology.explanation: The Unknowable; beyond ordinary comprehension; transcends intellect
Thousand-Rayed; like the sun; infinite radiance; illumines all
The Creator; ordainer of destinies; cosmic architect
Who Has Distinguished Marks; bears auspicious signs; or creator of characteristics

lines.meaning: Center of Light-Rays, Established in Sattva, the Lion, and Great Lord of All Beings
lines.note: Shloka 51 first half.

etymology.explanation: Center of Light-Rays; hub of radiance; around whom brilliance revolves
Established in Sattva; abides in pure goodness; beyond rajas and tamas
The Lion; Narasimha; destroys evil; king of beasts
Great Lord of All Beings; supreme ruler of all creatures

lines.meaning: The Primordial God, the Great God, Lord of Gods, and Guru who Sustains the Gods
lines.note: Shloka 51 complete. Crossing the 500 mark with Gopati.

etymology.explanation: The Primordial God; first deity; original divine being
The Great God; supreme deity; transcends all others
Lord of Gods; ruler of all devas; master of celestials
Guru who Sustains the Gods; teacher of those who support devas; or guru of Indra

lines.meaning: The Superior, Lord of Earth/Senses, the Protector, Attainable through Knowledge, and the Ancient
lines.note: Shloka 52 first half. Gopati marks the 500th name.

etymology.explanation: The Superior; who delivers across samsara; transcendent
Lord of Earth/Senses; Krishna the cowherd; master of all
The Protector; guardian of all; shields devotees
Attainable through Knowledge; reached by wisdom; known through jñāna
The Ancient One; existing from time immemorial; eternal

lines.meaning: Sustainer of Beings in Bodies, the Enjoyer, Lord of Monkeys, and Of Abundant Generosity
lines.note: Shloka 52 complete. Kapīndra refers to Rama's association with Hanuman.

etymology.explanation: Sustainer of Beings in Bodies; supports all embodied beings; inner sustainer
The Enjoyer; experiences through all beings; ultimate experiencer
Lord of Monkeys; Rama who commanded the Vanaras; friend of Hanuman
Of Abundant Generosity; gives liberally; bestows countless gifts

lines.meaning: Drinker of Soma, Drinker of Nectar, the Moon, Conqueror of Many, and Best among Men
lines.note: Shloka 53 first half.

etymology.explanation: Drinker of Soma; receives the sacred offering; enjoyer of yajña
Drinker of Nectar; immortal; sustainer of devas with amṛta
The Moon; source of amṛta; nourisher of plants and herbs
Conqueror of Many; vanquisher of numerous foes; victorious over all
Best among Men; Purushottama; supreme person

lines.deva: विनयो जयः सत्यसन्धो दाशार्हः सात्वतां पतिः ॥
lines.iast: vinayō jayaḥ satyasandhō dāśārhaḥ sātvatāṃ patiḥ ॥
lines.knda: ವಿನಯೋ ಜಯಃ ಸತ್ಯಸಂಧೋ ದಾಶಾರ್ಹಃ ಸಾತ್ವತಾಂ ಪತಿಃ ॥
lines.tel: వినయో జయః సత్యసంధో దాశార్హః సాత్వతాం పతిః ॥
lines.tam: வினயோ ஜய: ஸத்யஸந்தோ⁴ தா³ஶார்ஹ: ஸாத்வதாம் பதி: ॥
lines.guj: વિનયો જયઃ સત્યસંધો દાશાર્હઃ સાત્વતાં પતિઃ ॥
lines.pan: ਵਿਨਯੋ ਜਯਃ ਸਤ੍ਯਸਂਧੋ ਦਾਸ਼ਾਰ੍ਹਃ ਸਾਤ੍ਵਤਾਂ ਪਤਿਃ ॥
lines.mr: विनयो जयः सत्यसंधो दाशार्हः सात्वतां पतिः ॥
lines.meaning: The Humble, Victory, True to His Word, Descendent of Dasharha, and Lord of Satvatas
lines.note: Shloka 53 complete. Krishna references with Dasharha and Satvata.

etymology.explanation: The Humble; embodies discipline; leads beings to propriety
Victory; ever triumphant; conquest personified
True to His Word; whose promise never fails; keeper of vows
Descendent of Dasharha; Krishna of the Yadava clan
Lord of the Satvatas; Krishna's devotees; Yadava clan

lines.meaning: The Life, the Discipliner, the Witness, Giver of Liberation, and Of Unlimited Prowess
lines.note: Shloka 54 first half. Features the beloved name Mukunda.

etymology.explanation: The Life; animating principle; inner self of all beings
The Discipliner; trains and refines beings; brings propriety
The Witness; observes all without participating; eternal observer
Giver of Liberation; bestows moksha; one of the most beloved names
Of Unlimited Prowess; boundless valor; infinite heroism

lines.meaning: Ocean of Waters, the Infinite Self, Who Reclines on the Great Ocean, and the Ender
lines.note: Shloka 54 complete.

etymology.explanation: Ocean of Waters; cosmic ocean; repository of all existence
The Infinite Self; boundless consciousness; eternal spirit
Who Reclines on the Great Ocean; Vishnu on Shesha in the cosmic waters
The Ender; brings dissolution; destroyer at pralaya

lines.meaning: The Unborn, Worthy of Great Worship, Self-Existent, Conqueror of Enemies, and the Delightful
lines.note: Shloka 55 first half.

etymology.explanation: The Unborn; without origin; eternal and uncreated
Worthy of Great Worship; deserving supreme honor; most revered
Self-Existent by Nature; naturally eternal; inherently divine
Conqueror of Enemies; vanquisher of foes; victorious over asuras
The Delightful; gives supreme joy; source of bliss

lines.meaning: Bliss, the Delighter, Joy, Of True Dharma, and Who Took Three Strides
lines.note: Shloka 55 complete. Features Trivikrama (Vamana avatar).

etymology.explanation: Bliss; supreme happiness; Sat-Chit-Ananda
The Delighter; gives joy to devotees; source of delight
Joy; happiness personified; also foster-father of Krishna
Of True Dharma; whose nature is truthful righteousness
Who Took Three Strides; Vamana avatar who measured the three worlds

lines.meaning: The Great Sage, Kapila the Teacher, the Grateful One, and Lord of the Earth
lines.note: Shloka 56 first half. Kapilāchārya is the founder of Sankhya darshana.

etymology.explanation: The Great Sage; supreme among seers; source of wisdom
Kapila the Teacher; founder of Sankhya philosophy; avatar of Vishnu
The Grateful One; remembers even small offerings; appreciates devotion
Lord of the Earth; sovereign of the world; Varaha who lifted Earth

lines.meaning: Of Three Steps, Overlord of the Gods, Great-Horned, and Destroyer of Death
lines.note: Shloka 56 complete. Mahāśṛṅga refers to Matsya avatar.

etymology.explanation: Of Three Steps; Vamana's three strides; pervades three worlds
Overlord of the Gods; presides over all devas; supreme among celestials
Great-Horned; Matsya avatar with the great horn; also peak of Meru
Destroyer of Death; conquers Yama; overcomes mortality

lines.meaning: The Great Boar, Govinda, Of Excellent Army, and With Golden Armlets
lines.note: Shloka 57 first half. Features Varaha and the beloved name Govinda.

etymology.explanation: The Great Boar; Varaha avatar who lifted Earth from cosmic waters
Govinda; finder of cows; lord of senses; beloved name of Krishna
Of Excellent Army; possessing good forces; commander of divine hosts
With Golden Armlets; adorned with golden ornaments; divine beauty

lines.meaning: The Secret, the Profound, the Unfathomable, the Hidden, and Bearer of Discus and Mace
lines.note: Shloka 57 complete.

etymology.explanation: The Secret; hidden in the heart; esoteric truth
The Profound; of unfathomable depth; incomprehensible nature
The Unfathomable; impenetrable; difficult to comprehend
The Hidden; concealed; protected by māyā
Bearer of Discus and Mace; holds Sudarshana and Kaumodaki; four-armed Vishnu

lines.meaning: The Creator, Of Beautiful Limbs, the Unconquered, Krishna, the Firm, Sankarshana, and the Infallible
lines.note: Shloka 58 first half. Features Krishna and Sankarshana (Balarama).

etymology.explanation: The Creator; who ordains and creates; Brahma's source
Of Beautiful Limbs; possesses perfect divine form; self-sufficient body
The Unconquered; never defeated; invincible
Krishna; the Dark One; who attracts all; most beloved avatar
The Firm; steadfast; unwavering resolve
Sankarshana; Balarama; who draws all at pralaya; elder brother of Krishna
The Infallible; never falls from glory; eternally perfect

lines.meaning: Varuna, Son of Varuna, the Tree, Lotus-Eyed, and Great-Minded
lines.note: Shloka 58 complete.

etymology.explanation: Varuna; god of waters and cosmic order; inner controller of Varuna
Son of Varuna; or who presides over the western direction
The Tree; Ashvattha tree of samsara; immovable and sheltering
Lotus-Eyed; with eyes beautiful as lotuses; divine vision
Great-Minded; of vast intellect; supremely generous spirit

lines.meaning: The Blessed Lord, Destroyer of Fortune (of foes), the Joyful, Wearer of Forest Garland, and Wielder of the Plough
lines.note: Shloka 59 first half. Features Bhagavan and Vanamali.

etymology.explanation: The Blessed Lord; possessor of six divine qualities; most sacred title
Destroyer of Fortune; takes away the glory of enemies; protector of devotees
The Joyful; ever blissful; embodiment of happiness
Wearer of Forest Garland; adorned with Vaijayanti garland; Krishna's iconic form
Wielder of the Plough; Balarama; elder brother of Krishna

lines.meaning: Son of Aditi, Light among the Suns, the Enduring, and the Best Refuge
lines.note: Shloka 59 complete.

etymology.explanation: Son of Aditi; the Sun; Vamana born to Aditi; among the twelve Adityas
Light among the Suns; source of all radiance; illuminator of luminaries
The Enduring; supremely patient; tolerates all
The Best Refuge; supreme destination; ultimate goal

lines.meaning: Excellent Bow, With Broken Axe (Parashurama), the Fierce, and Giver of Wealth
lines.note: Shloka 60 first half. Features Parashurama avatar.

etymology.explanation: Excellent Bow; wielder of the divine bow; Rama with Sharanga
With Broken Axe; Parashurama; whose axe cleaved the kshatriyas
The Fierce; terrible to the wicked; severe in punishment
Giver of Wealth; bestows riches; fulfills material desires

lines.meaning: Touching the Sky, All-Seeing Vyasa, Lord of Speech, and Not Born of Womb
lines.note: Shloka 60 complete. Features Vyasa avatar.

etymology.explanation: Touching the Sky; reaches the heavens; Trivikrama's cosmic form
All-Seeing Vyasa; who divided the Vedas; omniscient compiler
Lord of Speech; master of all words; eloquence personified
Not Born of Womb; self-manifested; without material origin

lines.deva: त्रिसामा सामगः साम निर्वाणं भेषजं भिषक् ।
lines.iast: trisāmā sāmagaḥ sāma nirvāṇaṃ bhēṣajaṃ bhiṣak ।
lines.knda: ತ್ರಿಸಾಮಾ ಸಾಮಗಃ ಸಾಮ ನಿರ್ವಾಣಂ ಭೇಷಜಂ ಭಿಷಕ್ ।
lines.tel: త్రిసామా సామగః సామ నిర్వాణం భేషజం భిషక్ ।
lines.tam: த்ரிஸாமா ஸாமக:³ ஸாம நிர்வாணம் பே⁴ஷஜம் பி⁴ஷக் ।
lines.guj: ત્રિસામા સામગઃ સામ નિર્વાણં ભેષજં ભિષક્ ।
lines.pan: ਤ੍ਰਿਸਾਮਾ ਸਾਮਗਃ ਸਾਮ ਨਿਰ੍ਵਾਣਂ ਭੇਸ਼ਜਂ ਭਿਸ਼ਕ੍ ।
lines.mr: त्रिसामा सामगः साम निर्वाणं भेषजं भिषक् ।
lines.meaning: Praised by Three Samans, Singer of Sama, the Sama Veda, Liberation, the Medicine, and the Physician
lines.note: Shloka 61 first half. Features Vedic and healing aspects.

etymology.explanation: Praised by Three Samans; glorified by Devavrata, Rathantara, Brihatsama
Singer of Sama; chants the melodious Sama Veda; musical deity
The Sama Veda; embodiment of melody and peace; music itself
Liberation; extinction of suffering; supreme bliss of moksha
The Medicine; cure for samsara; remedy for all ills
The Physician; divine doctor; healer of spiritual disease

lines.ben: ত্রিসামা সামগঃ সাম নির্বাণং ভেষজং ভিষক্ ।
lines.mal: ത്രിസാമാ സാമഗഃ സാമ നിർവാണം ഭേഷജം ഭിഷക് ।
lines.meaning: Establisher of Renunciation, Tranquility, the Peaceful, the Firm Ground, Peace, and Ultimate Refuge
lines.note: Shloka 61 complete.

etymology.explanation: Establisher of Renunciation; creator of sannyasa; teaches letting go
Tranquility; mental peace; control of the senses
The Peaceful; serene; undisturbed by passions
The Firm Ground; foundation of knowledge; ultimate resting place
Peace; the supreme peace that passes understanding
The Ultimate Refuge; final goal; highest destination

lines.meaning: Of Auspicious Limbs, Giver of Peace, the Creator, Delighting in Earth, and Reclining on Earth
lines.note: Shloka 62 first half.

etymology.explanation: Of Auspicious Limbs; divine form; beautiful sacred body
Giver of Peace; bestows tranquility to devotees
The Creator; who projects the universe; source of creation
Delighting in Earth; or white lotus; joyful on the earth
Reclining on Earth; or on the blue lotus; cosmic repose

lines.meaning: Benefactor of Cows, Lord of Cows, the Protector, Bull-Eyed, and Fond of Dharma
lines.note: Shloka 62 complete. Crossed the 600-name milestone with Gohita.

etymology.explanation: Benefactor of Cows; protector of cattle and earth; Krishna the cowherd
Lord of Cows; master of cattle; Krishna
The Protector; guardian of all beings; divine shepherd
Bull-Eyed; with large powerful eyes; majestic glance like a bull
Fond of Dharma; loves righteousness; delights in virtue

lines.meaning: Never Turning Back, Whose Self is Withdrawn, the Contracter, Doer of Good, and the Auspicious
lines.note: Shloka 63 first half.

etymology.explanation: Never Turning Back; steadfast; never retreats from protecting devotees
Whose Self is Withdrawn; detached from worldly objects; established in self
The Contracter; withdraws creation at pralaya; compresses the universe
Doer of Good; creates welfare; protects what is gained
The Auspicious; embodiment of blessedness; pure and holy

lines.meaning: With Shrivatsa on Chest, Abode of Shri, Lord of Shri, and Best among the Glorious
lines.note: Shloka 63 complete. Features Shri (Lakshmi) names.

etymology.explanation: With Shrivatsa on His Chest; bears the auspicious curl on chest; mark of Lakshmi
Abode of Shri; where Lakshmi eternally resides; repository of fortune
Lord of Shri; husband of Lakshmi; master of all fortune
Best among the Glorious; most excellent of all wealthy and auspicious beings

lines.meaning: Giver of Shri, Lord of Shri, In Whom Shri Dwells, Treasury of Shri, and Manifester of Shri
lines.note: Shloka 64 first half. Continues the beautiful Shri-names.

etymology.explanation: Giver of Shri; bestows wealth and auspiciousness
Lord of Shri; master of Lakshmi and all fortune
In Whom Shri Dwells; Lakshmi's eternal home; Tirupati Lord's name
Treasury of Shri; storehouse of all fortune and beauty
Manifester of Shri; creates and reveals fortune; source of prosperity

lines.meaning: Bearer of Shri, Maker of Shri, the Supreme Good, the Glorious, and Shelter of Three Worlds
lines.note: Shloka 64 complete. Completes the majestic Shri-nama sequence.

etymology.explanation: Bearer of Shri; holds Lakshmi on his chest; supports all fortune
Maker of Shri; creates prosperity; bestows grace
The Supreme Good; highest welfare; ultimate blessedness
The Glorious; endowed with Shri; possessor of all divine attributes
Shelter of Three Worlds; refuge of heaven, earth, and underworld

lines.meaning: Beautiful-Eyed, Beautiful-Limbed, Of Hundred Joys, Bliss, and Lord of the Host of Lights
lines.note: Shloka 65 first half.

etymology.explanation: Beautiful-Eyed; with captivating eyes; divine vision
Beautiful-Limbed; with perfect divine form; graceful body
Of Hundred Joys; infinite bliss; source of countless delights
Bliss; happiness personified; pure joy
Lord of the Host of Lights; ruler of celestial luminaries; master of all radiance

lines.meaning: Self-Conquered, Whose Self Cannot Be Commanded, Of True Fame, and Dispeller of Doubts
lines.note: Shloka 65 complete.

etymology.explanation: Self-Conquered; master of his own self; perfect self-control
Whose Self Cannot Be Commanded; beyond anyone's control; independent
Of True Fame; whose glory is real; genuinely renowned
Dispeller of Doubts; removes all uncertainties; bestows clarity

lines.meaning: The Elevated, Eyes Everywhere, Without a Superior, the Eternal, and the Steady
lines.note: Shloka 66 first half.

etymology.explanation: The Elevated; transcendent; risen above all
Eyes Everywhere; all-seeing; omniscient perceiver
Without a Superior; has no master; supreme ruler
The Eternal; everlasting; permanent across all time
The Steady; unwavering; immovable in nature

lines.meaning: Reclining on Earth, the Ornament, Glory, Free from Sorrow, and Destroyer of Sorrow
lines.note: Shloka 66 complete.

etymology.explanation: Reclining on Earth; sleeps on the earth; all-pervading rest
The Ornament; adorns the world; beauty of creation
Glory; prosperity; divine splendor and power
Free from Sorrow; ever blissful; untouched by grief
Destroyer of Sorrow; removes grief of devotees; healer of hearts

lines.meaning: The Radiant, the Worshipped, the Container, Pure-Souled, and the Purifier
lines.note: Shloka 67 first half.

etymology.explanation: The Radiant; full of brilliance; effulgent
The Worshipped; revered by all; object of adoration
The Container; holds everything within; cosmic womb
Pure-Souled; supremely pure; untouched by any impurity
The Purifier; cleanses sins; sanctifies devotees

lines.meaning: The Unobstructed, the Matchless in Battle, Pradyumna (the Eminently Mighty), the One of Infinite Valor
lines.note: Shloka 67 second half. Contains two Vyuha forms - Aniruddha and Pradyumna.

etymology.explanation: The Unobstructed; fourth of the Vyuha forms; Krishna's grandson; one whom no enemy can resist
One who has no equal opponent in battle; matchless warrior
The Eminently Mighty; third Vyuha form; Krishna's son; incarnation of Kama
One of immeasurable valor; whose steps/heroism know no bounds; Trivikrama

lines.meaning: Slayer of Kalanemi, the Heroic, son of Shura, Lord of the Heroic
lines.note: Shloka 68 first half. References Krishna's lineage through Shura.

etymology.explanation: Slayer of demon Kalanemi; the demon who was killed by Vishnu and reborn as Kamsa
The Heroic One; supreme among the valiant; the eternal warrior
Descendant of Shura; Krishna as grandson of Shura through Vasudeva
Lord of heroic people; sovereign of the Yadava warriors

lines.meaning: Soul of the Three Worlds, Lord of the Three Worlds, Keshava, Slayer of Keshi, Hari
lines.note: Shloka 68 second half. Keshava and Keshiha reference Krishna's beautiful hair and his slaying of demon Keshi.

etymology.explanation: Soul of the three worlds; the inner self pervading heaven, earth, and netherworld
Lord of the three worlds; sovereign ruler of all existence
One with beautiful hair; or Lord of the Trinity (Ka=Brahma, A=Vishnu, Isha=Shiva)
Slayer of the horse-demon Keshi; young Krishna's victory in Vrindavan
The Remover of sins and sorrows; one who captivates hearts; the green/golden one

lines.meaning: God of Desire, Protector of Desires, the Desirous One, the Beloved, Author of Scriptures
lines.note: Shloka 69 first half. Series of Kama-related names celebrating the Lord as ultimate fulfiller of desires.

etymology.explanation: God of desire; the One sought by all beings; more desirable than Kamadeva himself
Protector of righteous desires; fulfiller and guardian of devotees' wishes
One who desires; whose desire is for the welfare of beings; or one who is desirable
The Beloved; supremely attractive; the most beautiful and lovable
Author of scriptures; the source of Vedas, Agamas, and all sacred knowledge

lines.meaning: Of Indescribable Form, All-Pervading (Vishnu), the Hero, the Infinite, Winner of Wealth
lines.note: Shloka 69 second half. Vishnu appears as the 667th name, affirming His all-pervading nature.

etymology.explanation: One whose form cannot be described; transcending all description and conception
The All-Pervading; one who pervades and permeates everything in existence
The Hero; endowed with supreme valor and courage
The Infinite; without limits in time, space, or attributes; Shesha serpent
Winner of wealth; Arjuna's name; one who conquers all treasures for dharma

lines.meaning: Patron of Brahmanas, Creator of Brahma, the Creator (Brahma), the Absolute (Brahman), Nourisher of Brahman
lines.note: Shloka 70 first half. Series of five Brahman-related names showing Vishnu as source and sustainer of all.

etymology.explanation: Favorably disposed to Brahmanas and Vedic knowledge; protector of dharma
Creator of Brahma; establisher of the Vedas
The Creator deity; the vast one; Vishnu as the source of Brahma
The Absolute Reality; the infinite unchanging truth; Parabrahman
One who increases Vedic knowledge; nourisher of spiritual growth

lines.meaning: Knower of Brahman, the Great Brahmana, Possessor of Brahman, Knower of Absolute, Dear to Brahmanas
lines.note: Shloka 70 second half. Continues the ten Brahman-related names, celebrating the Lord's connection to ultimate Reality.

etymology.explanation: Knower of Brahman; one who perfectly knows the Absolute Reality
The Supreme Brahmana; the ultimate knower of Brahman
Possessor of Brahman; established in Brahman; the Brahmic consciousness
One who knows the Absolute; the perfect knower of supreme truth
Dear to Brahmanas; one who loves those established in Brahman

lines.meaning: Of Great Strides, of Great Deeds, of Great Splendor, the Great Serpent
lines.note: Shloka 71 first half. Series of Maha- (great) names affirming supreme magnificence.

etymology.explanation: One of great strides; Trivikrama who covered the universe in three steps
Performer of great deeds; whose actions create and sustain the universe
Of great splendor; possessing supreme effulgence and brilliance
The Great Serpent; Ananta-Shesha on whom He reclines; cosmic serpent

lines.meaning: The Great Sacrifice, the Great Sacrificer, the Great Yajna, the Great Oblation
lines.note: Shloka 71 second half. Continues Maha- names with yajna-related epithets.

etymology.explanation: The Great Sacrifice; supreme Vedic ritual personified; also great determination
The Great Performer of Sacrifices; one who performs cosmic yajna
The Great Yajna itself; the supreme sacrifice that sustains creation
The Great Oblation; the supreme offering in all sacrifices

lines.deva: स्तव्यः स्तवप्रियः स्तोत्रं स्तुतिः स्तोता रणप्रियः ।
lines.iast: stavyaḥ stavapriyaḥ stōtraṃ stutiḥ stōtā raṇapriyaḥ ।
lines.knda: ಸ್ತವ್ಯಃ ಸ್ತವಪ್ರಿಯಃ ಸ್ತೋತ್ರಂ ಸ್ತುತಿಃ ಸ್ತೋತಾ ರಣಪ್ರಿಯಃ ।
lines.tel: స్తవ్యః స్తవప్రియః స్తోత్రం స్తుతిః స్తోతా రణప్రియః ।
lines.tam: ஸ்தவ்ய: ஸ்தவப்ரிய: ஸ்தோத்ரம் ஸ்துதி: ஸ்தோதா ரணப்ரிய: ।
lines.guj: સ્તવ્યઃ સ્તવપ્રિયઃ સ્તોત્રં સ્તુતિઃ સ્તોતા રણપ્રિયઃ ।
lines.pan: ਸ੍ਤਵ੍ਯਃ ਸ੍ਤਵਪ੍ਰਿਯਃ ਸ੍ਤੋਤ੍ਰਂ ਸ੍ਤੁਤਿਃ ਸ੍ਤੋਤਾ ਰਣਪ੍ਰਿਯਃ ।
lines.mr: स्तव्यः स्तवप्रियः स्तोत्रं स्तुतिः स्तोता रणप्रियः ।
lines.meaning: Worthy of Praise, Lover of Praise, the Hymn, the Eulogy, the Praiser, Lover of Battle
lines.note: Shloka 72 first half. Series of five Stuti-related names plus Ranapriya.

etymology.explanation: One worthy of being praised; deserving all hymns and laudations
One who loves praise; delighted by devotees' hymns and prayers
The Hymn itself; the very essence of all sacred praise
The Eulogy; the act of praising personified
The Praiser; one who praises (as the inner Self inspiring devotees)
Lover of righteous battle; delighting in dharma-yuddha for protection of good

lines.ben: স্তব্য়ঃ স্তবপ্রিয়ঃ স্তোত্রং স্তুতিঃ স্তোতা রণপ্রিয়ঃ ।
lines.mal: സ്തവ്യഃ സ്തവപ്രിയഃ സ്തോത്രം സ്തുതിഃ സ്തോതാ രണപ്രിയഃ ।
lines.meaning: The Complete, the Fulfiller, the Pure/Holy, of Holy Fame, Free from Disease
lines.note: Shloka 72 second half. Approaching 700th name - the Purna/Punya series.

etymology.explanation: The Complete; full of all excellences; lacking nothing
The Fulfiller; one who completes and fulfills devotees' desires
The Holy One; supremely pure; whose remembrance confers merit
One of holy fame; whose glory purifies and sanctifies all
Free from disease; perfect health personified; curer of all maladies

lines.meaning: Swift as Mind, Creator of Sacred Waters, of Golden Seed, Bestower of Wealth
lines.note: Shloka 73 first half. 700th name milestone - Manojavah marks 70% completion.

etymology.explanation: Swift as the mind; faster than thought; omnipresent instantly
Creator of holy waters; establisher of sacred pilgrimage sites; redeemer
One whose seed is gold; Hiranyagarbha; source of all treasures
Bestower of wealth; giver of all treasures and prosperity

lines.meaning: Giver of Wealth, Son of Vasudeva, the Treasure, Good-Minded, the Oblation
lines.note: Shloka 73 second half. Contains Vasudeva (705) - the most sacred name of Krishna.

etymology.explanation: Bestower of wealth; giver of liberation as the supreme treasure
Son of Vasudeva; Krishna; also one who dwells in all and in whom all dwell
The Treasure; one who dwells in all; the supreme wealth
Good-minded; whose mind is pure wealth; benevolent to all
The Oblation; the sacred offering in all sacrifices

lines.meaning: The Good Destination, Good Action, Existence, True Glory, Supreme Refuge of the Good
lines.note: Shloka 74 first half. Series of five Sat (truth/existence) names.

etymology.explanation: The Good Destination; supreme goal of the righteous; liberating path
Good Action personified; source of all righteous deeds
Pure Existence; the very principle of being; Sat aspect of Sat-Chit-Ananda
True Glory; prosperity in its highest form; auspicious existence
Supreme Refuge of the good; final goal of the righteous

lines.meaning: Commander of Heroic Army, Best among Yadus, the Abode, Connected with Yamuna
lines.note: Shloka 74 second half. Krishna's connection to Mathura region and Yadava lineage.

etymology.explanation: Commander of heroic armies; born in Shurasena region (Mathura); lord of valiant warriors
Best among the Yadavas; supreme member of the Yadu dynasty
The Abode; where all beings dwell; ultimate resting place of souls
Well connected with Yamuna; Krishna who sported on Yamuna's banks

lines.meaning: Abode of Beings, Son of Vasudeva, Abode of All Life-breaths, the Fire
lines.note: Shloka 75 first half. Vasudeva appears again as the 719th name.

etymology.explanation: Abode of all beings; in whom all creatures reside; the cosmic home
Son of Vasudeva; Krishna; also dweller in all and all-pervading light
Abode of all life-breaths; source and resting place of all prāṇa
Fire; one whose power is never enough (insatiable); cosmic fire principle

lines.meaning: Destroyer of Pride, Giver of Pride, the Proud, Difficult to Bear, the Unconquered
lines.note: Shloka 75 second half. Names related to pride and invincibility.

etymology.explanation: Destroyer of false pride; humbler of the arrogant
Giver of righteous pride; one who grants confidence to devotees
The Proud One; supremely confident; reveling in divine glory
Difficult to bear; incomprehensible to the wicked; overwhelming
The Unconquered; never defeated by anyone; eternally victorious

lines.meaning: Cosmic Form, Great Form, Radiant Form, the Formless One
lines.note: Shloka 76 first half. Murti series showing both manifest and unmanifest aspects.

etymology.explanation: One whose form is the universe; the Cosmic Form shown to Arjuna
One of great form; whose form is immeasurably vast
One of radiant form; blazing with divine effulgence
The Formless One; transcending all forms yet possessing infinite forms

lines.meaning: Of Many Forms, the Unmanifest, of Hundred Forms, of Hundred Faces
lines.note: Shloka 76 second half. Continues the Murti theme - multiple and infinite forms.

etymology.explanation: One of many forms; manifesting in countless forms throughout creation
The Unmanifest; beyond sense perception; subtle primordial nature
One of hundred forms; innumerable manifestations
One of hundred faces; the cosmic form with countless faces

lines.deva: एको नैकः स्तवः कः किं यत्तत् पदमनुत्तमम् ।
lines.iast: ēkō naikaḥ stavaḥ kaḥ kiṃ yattat padamanuttamam ।
lines.knda: ಏಕೋ ನೈಕಃ ಸ್ತವಃ ಕಃ ಕಿಂ ಯತ್ತತ್ ಪದಮನುತ್ತಮಮ್ ।
lines.tel: ఏకో నైకః స్తవః కః కిం యత్తత్ పదమనుత్తమమ్ ।
lines.tam: ஏகோ நைக: ஸ்தவ: க: கிம் யத்தத் பத³மனுத்தமம் ।
lines.guj: એકો નૈકઃ સ્તવઃ કઃ કિં યત્તત્ પદમનુત્તમમ્ ।
lines.pan: ਏਕੋ ਨੈਕਃ ਸ੍ਤਵਃ ਕਃ ਕਿਂ ਯਤ੍ਤਤ੍ ਪਦਮਨੁਤ੍ਤਮਮ੍ ।
lines.mr: एको नैकः स्तवः कः किं यत्तत् पदमनुत्तमम् ।
lines.meaning: The One, the Many, the Hymn, Who?, What?, That-This, the Supreme State
lines.note: Shloka 77 first half. Philosophical names using pronominal forms.

etymology.explanation: The One; without a second; the non-dual reality
The Many; manifesting as many while being one
The Hymn itself; embodiment of all praise and worship
The Who; the answer to all questions; also Brahma
The What; the reality sought by all inquiry
That Supreme State; the unsurpassed abode; Parama Pada

lines.ben: একো নৈকঃ স্তবঃ কঃ কিং যত্তত্ পদমনুত্তমম্ ।
lines.mal: ഏകോ നൈകഃ സ്തവഃ കഃ കിം യത്തത് പദമനുത്തമമ് ।
lines.meaning: Friend of the World, Lord of the World, Madhava (Lord of Fortune), Loving to Devotees
lines.note: Shloka 77 second half. Madhava and Bhaktavatsala - beloved devotional names.

etymology.explanation: Friend of the world; related to all beings as their well-wisher
Lord of the worlds; protector and master of all creation
Lord of Lakshmi; also descendant of Madhu; consort of Sri
Loving to devotees; tenderly affectionate to His devotees like a cow to her calf

lines.meaning: Of Golden Complexion, of Golden Limbs, of Beautiful Limbs, Wearing Sandal Paste and Armlets
lines.note: Shloka 78 first half. Physical beauty names - the Lord's golden divine form.

etymology.explanation: Of golden complexion; resplendent with golden hue
One with golden limbs; body shining like gold
One of beautiful limbs; perfect divine form
Wearing sandal paste and armlets; adorned with fragrant ornaments

lines.meaning: Slayer of Heroes, the Incomparable, the Void, Whose Food is Ghee, Immovable, Movable
lines.note: Shloka 78 second half. Paradoxical pairs - both immovable (Acala) and movable (Chala).

etymology.explanation: Slayer of demon heroes; destroyer of evil warriors
The Incomparable; unequal to any; without parallel
The Void; devoid of all worldly qualities; transcendent
One whose food is ghee; accepting oblations of clarified butter
The Immovable; eternally stable; unchanging
The Movable; pervading all as moving principle; the cosmic motion

lines.meaning: Without Pride, Giver of Honor, the Honored One, Lord of the World, Upholder of Three Worlds
lines.note: Shloka 79 first half. Mana series - the humble yet supreme Lord.

etymology.explanation: Without pride; free from ego; humble despite supreme glory
Giver of honor; bestowing respect and dignity to devotees
The Honored One; worthy of all respect and worship
Lord of the worlds; sovereign master of all creation
Upholder of the three worlds; sustaining heaven, earth, and netherworld

lines.meaning: Of Good Intelligence, Born of Sacrifice, the Blessed, of True Wisdom, Supporter of Earth
lines.note: Shloka 79 second half. Medha series - wisdom and sacrifice.

etymology.explanation: Of excellent wisdom; possessing supreme intelligence
Born of sacrifice; manifest through yajna; essence of rituals
The Blessed One; supremely fortunate; source of all blessings
Of true wisdom; whose understanding is always truthful
Supporter of the earth; upholder of the world as Varaha/Kurma

lines.meaning: Showerer of Splendor, Bearer of Radiance, Best among All Weapon-Bearers
lines.note: Shloka 80 first half. Splendor and martial prowess.

etymology.explanation: Showerer of splendor; one who rains down brilliance
Bearer of radiance; possessing divine effulgence
Best among all weapon-bearers; supreme wielder of divine weapons

lines.meaning: The Receiver, the Controller, the Engaged, of Many Horns, Elder Brother of Gada
lines.note: Shloka 80 second half. Includes Varaha reference (Naikashringah).

etymology.explanation: The Receiver; one who accepts offerings; guide of the senses
The Controller; one who restrains; subduer of the wicked
The Engaged; always active in protecting devotees
Of many horns; the cosmic boar Varaha with many tusks
Elder brother of Gada; Krishna's half-brother through Vasudeva

lines.meaning: Of Four Forms, Four-Armed, of Four Vyuhas, the Four Goals
lines.note: Shloka 81 first half. The Chatur (four) series begins - Vyuha theology.

etymology.explanation: One of four forms; the four Vyuha forms (Vasudeva, Sankarshana, Pradyumna, Aniruddha)
Four-armed; the classic Vishnu form with conch, disc, mace, lotus
One of four Vyuhas; the four divine emanations for creation and protection
The four goals; granter of dharma, artha, kama, moksha (four purusharthas)

lines.meaning: Four-Souled, of Four States, Knower of Four Vedas, One-Footed
lines.note: Shloka 81 second half. Completes Chatur series; Ekapāt references Purusha Sukta.

etymology.explanation: Four-souled; the inner self in waking, dream, sleep, and turiya states
Of four states; manifesting through dharma, jnana, vairagya, aishvarya
Knower of the four Vedas; source and master of all Vedic knowledge
One-footed; the universe is but one quarter of His glory (Purusha Sukta)

lines.meaning: Who Brings About Dissolution, the Unreturning Self, Unconquerable, Insurmountable
lines.note: Shloka 82 first half. Dur- (difficult) series begins.

etymology.explanation: One who brings about dissolution; the cosmic cycle of creation and dissolution
The Unreturning Self; one who need not return to samsara; the liberated
The Unconquerable; whom none can overcome
The Insurmountable; whose commands cannot be violated

lines.meaning: Hard to Attain, Inaccessible, the Fortress, Difficult to Dwell In, Slayer of Wicked Foes
lines.note: Shloka 82 second half. Continues Dur- series - the inaccessible protector.

etymology.explanation: Hard to attain; obtainable only through supreme devotion
Inaccessible; difficult to reach without devotion
The Fortress; impenetrable refuge; protector like an impregnable fort
Difficult to dwell in; whose heart is hard to enter without purity
Slayer of wicked foes; destroyer of the evil enemies of devotees

lines.meaning: Of Auspicious Limbs, Essence of the World, of Beautiful Threads, Expander of Threads
lines.note: Shloka 83 first half. Tantu (thread) metaphor for cosmic creation.

etymology.explanation: One with auspicious limbs; whose every part is supremely beautiful and sacred
Essence of the worlds; or one who moves through worlds like a deer
Of beautiful threads; whose creation is well-woven like threads
Expander of threads; one who expands the fabric of creation and lineages

lines.meaning: Doer of Indra's Deeds, of Great Deeds, the Accomplished One, Author of Scriptures
lines.note: Shloka 83 second half. Karma series - the supreme actor.

etymology.explanation: Doer of Indra-like deeds; performing supreme lordly actions
Of great deeds; whose actions sustain the universe
One whose deeds are accomplished; having completed all that needs to be done
Author of scriptures; establisher of Vedas and Agamas

lines.meaning: The Source/Originator, the Beautiful, Slayer of Sunda, Jewel-Naveled, Beautiful-Eyed
lines.note: Shloka 84 first half. 800th name milestone - Sunda marks 80% completion.

etymology.explanation: The Source; origin of all creation; from whom everything arises
The Beautiful; supremely handsome; source of all beauty
Slayer of demon Sunda; or the Beautiful One (variant of sundara)
Jewel-naveled; from whose navel the lotus of creation emerged
Beautiful-eyed; whose lotus eyes shower grace on devotees

lines.meaning: The Sun, Giver of Food/Strength, the Horned One, the Victorious, All-Knowing Victor
lines.note: Shloka 84 second half. Includes Matsya reference (Shringi).

etymology.explanation: The Sun; the radiant one; worthy of worship
Giver of food and strength; provider of nourishment and vitality
The Horned One; Matsya with horn; or supreme peak of existence
The Victorious; eternally triumphant over all
All-knowing victor; omniscient and eternally victorious

lines.meaning: Golden-Dotted (Om-marked), the Unshakable, Lord of All Lords of Speech
lines.note: Shloka 85 first half.

etymology.explanation: Golden-dotted; marked with Om (Vishnu's golden mark); or the supreme point
The Unshakable; whom nothing can disturb; eternally serene
Lord of all lords of speech; master of Brahma and all deities of learning

lines.meaning: The Great Lake, the Great Abyss, the Great Being, the Great Treasure
lines.note: Shloka 85 second half. Maha- series continues - cosmic vastness.

etymology.explanation: The Great Lake; unfathomable reservoir of grace; or great-hearted
The Great Abyss; unfathomable depth of existence; cosmic void
The Great Being; source of the five great elements; supreme existence
The Great Treasure; inexhaustible repository of all wealth and virtue

lines.meaning: Delighter of Earth, Giver of Earth, the Jasmine, the Rain-Cloud, the Purifier, the Wind
lines.note: Shloka 86 first half. Nature names - earth, flower, rain, and wind.

etymology.explanation: Delighter of the earth; or white water-lily; one who brings joy to creation
Giver like jasmine; or one who lifted the earth (Varaha)
The Jasmine; pure white like jasmine; fragrant and beautiful
The Rain-Cloud; showerer of blessings like rain; nourisher of all
The Purifier; one who cleanses all beings of sin
The Wind; cosmic breath; vital force pervading all

lines.meaning: Whose Food is Nectar, of Immortal Body, the Omniscient, Facing All Directions
lines.note: Shloka 86 second half. Immortality and omniscience names.

etymology.explanation: One whose food is nectar; or one who feeds immortality to devotees
Of immortal body; whose form is deathless nectar
The Omniscient; knower of everything past, present, and future
Facing all directions; with faces on all sides; the Cosmic Person

lines.meaning: Easily Attainable, of Noble Vows, the Perfected, Conqueror of Enemies, Tormentor of Foes
lines.note: Shloka 87 first half. Accessible despite supreme; enemy-conquering.

etymology.explanation: Easily attainable; accessible to sincere devotees despite being supreme
Of noble vows; whose resolves are auspicious; steadfast in righteous promises
The Perfected; eternally accomplished; needing no attainment
Conqueror of enemies; victorious over all foes
Tormentor of enemies; one who afflicts the wicked

lines.meaning: The Banyan Tree, the Fig Tree, the Peepal Tree, Slayer of Chanura and Andhra
lines.note: Shloka 87 second half. Tree metaphors for Brahman; Krishna's wrestling victory.

etymology.explanation: The Banyan Tree; growing downward with aerial roots; symbol of eternal Brahman
The Sacred Fig Tree; nourisher above all; celestial tree
The Peepal Tree; sacred cosmic tree described in Gita chapter 15
Slayer of wrestlers Chanura and Andhra; young Krishna's victory in Kamsa's arena

lines.meaning: Of Thousand Rays, Seven-Tongued (Fire), Seven Fuels, Seven Vehicles (Sun)
lines.note: Shloka 88 first half. Fire and Sun names - Sapta (seven) series.

etymology.explanation: Of thousand rays; the blazing sun; source of infinite light
Seven-tongued; fire with seven flames; Agni who consumes offerings
Seven fuels; accepting seven types of sacrificial fuel
Of seven vehicles; the Sun whose chariot has seven horses (days of week)

lines.meaning: Formless, Sinless, Inconceivable, Creator of Fear, Destroyer of Fear
lines.note: Shloka 88 second half. Paradox - both creates and destroys fear.

etymology.explanation: The Formless; transcending all physical forms; pure consciousness
The Sinless; free from all evil; supremely pure
The Inconceivable; beyond the grasp of thought; transcending mind
Creator of fear; terrifying to the wicked and unrighteous
Destroyer of fear; removing all fears from devotees

lines.meaning: Atomic, Vast, Subtle, Gross, Bearer of Qualities, Without Qualities, the Great
lines.note: Shloka 89 first half. Beautiful paradoxes - atomic yet vast, subtle yet gross, with and without qualities.

etymology.explanation: The Atomic; smaller than the smallest; present in the atom
The Vast; greater than the greatest; infinite in extent
The Subtle; fine and delicate; imperceptible essence
The Gross; manifest in gross forms; the visible universe
Bearer of qualities; possessing infinite auspicious attributes
Without qualities; transcending material gunas; pure consciousness
The Great; supremely magnificent; beyond all comparison

lines.meaning: Unsupported, Self-Supported, Beautiful-Faced, Primeval Lineage, Increaser of Lineage
lines.note: Shloka 89 second half. Self-existent nature and cosmic genealogy.

etymology.explanation: The Unsupported; needing no support; self-existent
Self-supported; sustaining oneself by own power
Beautiful-faced; of pleasing countenance; the divine face
The Primeval Lineage; ancestral to all creation; the first of all families
Increaser of lineages; one who multiplies and nourishes families

lines.meaning: Bearer of Burden, the Celebrated, the Yogi, Lord of Yogis, Fulfiller of All Desires
lines.note: Shloka 90 first half. Yoga mastery and wish-fulfillment.

etymology.explanation: Bearer of burden; one who lifted the earth (Varaha); sustainer of all
The Celebrated; one who is praised and spoken of in all scriptures
The Yogi; master of yoga; united with supreme consciousness
Lord of Yogis; the supreme master of all yogis
Fulfiller of all desires; one who grants every wish to devotees

lines.meaning: The Hermitage, the Ascetic, the Emaciated, Beautiful-Winged (Garuda), Rider of Wind
lines.note: Shloka 90 second half. Ascetic aspects and Garuda connection.

etymology.explanation: The Hermitage; resting place for spiritual seekers; the four ashramas
The Ascetic; one who causes others to toil spiritually; or supremely peaceful
The Emaciated; slender; or supremely patient and forbearing
Beautiful-winged; Garuda's form; or having beautiful leaves (Vedas)
Whose vehicle is the wind; riding Garuda who is swift as wind

lines.meaning: Bearer of Bow, Knowledge of Archery, the Rod of Justice, the Subduer, Self-Control
lines.note: Shloka 91 first half. Martial prowess and discipline - Rama references.

etymology.explanation: Bearer of the bow; Rama the supreme archer; wielder of Sharnga
The science of archery; embodiment of all martial knowledge
The Rod of Justice; the supreme punisher of the wicked
The Subduer; one who tames and controls all beings
Self-Control; the virtue of restraint personified

lines.meaning: The Unconquered, All-Enduring, the Controller, Without Restrictions, the Unrestrained
lines.note: Shloka 91 second half. Paradox of control - Controller yet unrestricted.

etymology.explanation: The Unconquered; never defeated by any force
The All-Enduring; bearing everything with patience
The Controller; who regulates all beings
Without Restrictions; not bound by any rules
The Unrestrained; beyond death (Yama)

lines.meaning: Full of Sattva, the Sattvic One, the True, Devoted to Truth and Dharma
lines.note: Shloka 92 first half. Satya/Sattva series - truth and purity.

etymology.explanation: Full of Sattva; abounding in pure goodness
The Sattvic One; embodiment of pure goodness
The True; the ultimate reality
Devoted to Truth and Dharma; upholder of eternal law

lines.meaning: The Goal, Worthy of Love, the Worthy One, Doer of Dear Things, Increaser of Joy
lines.note: Shloka 92 second half. Priya series - divine love and worthiness.

etymology.explanation: The Goal; the ultimate aim of all beings
Worthy of Love; deserving the highest devotion
The Worthy One; deserving all worship
Doer of Dear Things; who does what pleases devotees
Increaser of Joy; who increases the love of devotees

lines.meaning: Moving Through Space, the Light, Beautiful Lustre, Enjoyer of Offerings, All-Pervading
lines.note: Shloka 93 first half. Celestial light series - divine luminosity.

etymology.explanation: Moving Through Space; whose movement is through the ether
The Light; the self-luminous One
Beautiful Lustre; of exquisite splendor
Enjoyer of Offerings; who accepts sacrificial offerings
The All-Pervading; present everywhere

lines.meaning: The Sun, the Illuminator, the Sun-God, the Impeller, Sun-Eyed
lines.note: Shloka 93 second half. Surya/Solar series - five sun-related names.

etymology.explanation: The Sun; source of light and heat
The Illuminator; who illumines all
The Sun-God; the moving one in the sky
The Impeller; who stimulates all creation
Sun-Eyed; whose eyes are the sun

lines.meaning: The Infinite, Enjoyer of Oblations, the Enjoyer, Giver of Happiness, Born Many Times, First-Born
lines.note: Shloka 94 first half. Approaching 900th name milestone.

etymology.explanation: The Infinite; without beginning or end
Enjoyer of Oblations; who receives sacrificial offerings
The Enjoyer; who experiences all
Giver of Happiness; who bestows bliss
Born Many Times; who takes multiple births (avatars)
The First-Born; born before all creation

lines.meaning: The Unwearied, Ever-Patient, Substratum of the World, the Wonderful
lines.note: Shloka 94 second half. 900th name (Anirvinnah) - the Unwearied One.

etymology.explanation: The Unwearied; never tired of creation, preservation, and dissolution
Ever-Patient; always forgiving the faults of devotees
Substratum of the World; the foundation on which all worlds rest
The Wonderful; whose nature and deeds are beyond comprehension

lines.meaning: The Eternal, Most Ancient, the Tawny One (Kapila), the Monkey, the Imperishable
lines.note: Shloka 95 first half. Eternity and avatara references - Kapila and Hanuman.

etymology.explanation: The Eternal; existing from time immemorial
Most Ancient; the oldest of the old
The Tawny One; founder of Sankhya philosophy
The Monkey; reference to Hanuman or the boar form
The Imperishable; who never diminishes

lines.meaning: Giver of Auspiciousness, Creator of Svasti, Auspiciousness Itself, Enjoyer of Svasti, Giver of Auspicious Gifts
lines.note: Shloka 95 second half. Complete Svasti series - five auspiciousness names.

etymology.explanation: Giver of Auspiciousness; who bestows well-being
Creator of Svasti; who creates all that is beneficial
Auspiciousness Itself; the very embodiment of blessing
Enjoyer of Svasti; who experiences all blessings
Giver of Auspicious Gifts; who gives dakshina that brings well-being

lines.meaning: Not Fierce, Wearing Earrings, Holder of Discus, the Valiant, of Powerful Commands
lines.note: Shloka 96 first half. Divine attributes - gentleness, ornaments, weapons, power.

etymology.explanation: Not Fierce; gentle despite supreme power
Wearing Earrings; adorned with divine ornaments
Holder of the Discus; wielder of Sudarshana Chakra
The Valiant; of extraordinary prowess (Vamana reference)
Of Powerful Commands; whose orders are irresistible

lines.meaning: Beyond Words, Bearing All Words, the Cool One, Creator of Night
lines.note: Shloka 96 second half. Transcendence and cosmic cycles.

etymology.explanation: Beyond Words; transcending verbal description
Bearing All Words; object of all Vedic words
The Cool One; who gives coolness/relief to devotees
Creator of Night; who ordains cycles of time

lines.meaning: Not Cruel, the Charming One, Expert, Skillful, Best Among the Forgiving
lines.note: Shloka 97 first half. Gentle virtues - kindness, skill, and forgiveness.

etymology.explanation: Not Cruel; gentle and compassionate to all
The Charming One; of pleasing form and manner
The Expert; skilled in all actions
The Skillful; liberal in rewarding devotees
Best Among the Forgiving; supreme in patience

lines.meaning: Most Learned, Free From Fear, Whose Hearing and Recital Brings Merit
lines.note: Shloka 97 second half. Phala-shruti reference - merits of recitation.

etymology.explanation: Most Learned; the wisest among all
Free From Fear; fearless and removing fear from devotees
Whose Hearing and Recital Brings Merit; listening to and singing about whom confers puṇya

lines.meaning: The Deliverer, Destroyer of Sins, the Holy, Destroyer of Bad Dreams
lines.note: Shloka 98 first half. Protective names - salvation, sin removal, purification.

etymology.explanation: The Deliverer; who helps cross the ocean of samsara
Destroyer of Sins; who removes all evil deeds
The Holy; who is supremely sacred
Destroyer of Bad Dreams; whose remembrance dispels nightmares

lines.meaning: Slayer of Heroes, the Protector, the Good, Life-Giver, Fully Established
lines.note: Shloka 98 second half. Protective and life-sustaining qualities.

etymology.explanation: Slayer of Heroes; who vanquishes mighty foes
The Protector; who guards all beings
The Good; embodiment of all virtues
The Life-Giver; who is the life of all lives
Fully Established; present everywhere completely

lines.meaning: Of Infinite Forms, of Infinite Glory, Conqueror of Anger, Remover of Fear
lines.note: Shloka 99 first half. Infinite attributes and fear-dispelling.

etymology.explanation: Of Infinite Forms; manifesting in countless forms
Of Infinite Glory; whose splendor is limitless
Conqueror of Anger; who has overcome all wrath
Remover of Fear; who dispels all fears

lines.meaning: Four-Sided, of Profound Nature, Giver of Directions, the Ordainer, the Directions
lines.note: Shloka 99 second half. Directional/spatial names - all-pervasive guidance.

etymology.explanation: Four-Sided; balanced and complete in all aspects
Of Profound Nature; unfathomable in essence
Giver of Special Directions; who guides uniquely
The Ordainer; who commands all
The Directions; pervading all quarters of space

lines.meaning: Without Beginning, the Earth, the Atmosphere, Glory/Lakshmi, the Heroic One, With Beautiful Armlets
lines.note: Shloka 100 first half. Milestone shloka! Cosmic and ornamental names.

etymology.explanation: Without Beginning; who has no origin
The Earth; the foundation of all existence
The Atmosphere; the middle world (antariksha)
Glory/Lakshmi; the abode of all prosperity
The Heroic One; possessing excellent valor
With Beautiful Armlets; adorned with resplendent ornaments

lines.meaning: The Creator, Origin of All Births, the Terrible, of Terrible Prowess
lines.note: Shloka 100 second half. Creation and fearsome power.

etymology.explanation: The Creator; who brings all beings into existence
Origin of All Births; the primordial cause of all life
The Terrible; whose power inspires awe
Of Terrible Prowess; whose valor is fearsome to enemies

lines.meaning: Abode of Support, Unsupported, Blooming Like a Flower, Ever Awake
lines.note: Shloka 101 first half. Foundation and awakening names.

etymology.explanation: Abode of Support; foundation upon which everything rests
The Unsupported; who needs no external support
Blooming Like a Flower; whose smile is like flowers blooming
Ever Awake; eternally vigilant, never sleeps

lines.meaning: Going Upward, Treading the Good Path, Giver of Life, the Pranava (Om), the Stake
lines.note: Shloka 101 second half. Sacred sound and life-giving names.

etymology.explanation: Going Upward; who ascends or leads souls upward
Treading the Good Path; who follows and teaches right conduct
Giver of Life; who bestows vital breath
The Pranava (Om); the sacred syllable, essence of Vedas
The Stake; whom devotees stake everything for

lines.meaning: The Authority/Measure, Abode of Life Breath, Sustainer of Life, Life of Life
lines.note: Shloka 102 first half. Complete Prana series - four life-breath names.

etymology.explanation: The Authority/Measure; the standard of all knowledge
Abode of Life Breath; where all pranas reside
Sustainer of Life; who maintains the vital force
Life of Life; the life-force behind all living

lines.meaning: The Reality, Knower of Reality, the One Self, Transcending Birth-Death-Old Age
lines.note: Shloka 102 second half. Philosophical names - truth and transcendence.

etymology.explanation: The Reality; the ultimate truth or essence
Knower of Reality; who knows all truths
The One Self; the single self of all beings
Transcending Birth-Death-Old Age; beyond the three afflictions

lines.meaning: Earth, Atmosphere, Heaven, the Tree, the Deliverer, the Impeller, Great-Grandfather
lines.note: Shloka 103 first half. Vyahritis (Bhur-Bhuvah-Svah) and ancestry.

etymology.explanation: The Earth; the physical world
The Atmosphere; the middle region
Heaven; the celestial world
The Tree; the cosmic tree of existence
The Deliverer; who helps cross the ocean of samsara
The Impeller; who stimulates all activity
Great-Grandfather; the progenitor of all, including Brahma

lines.meaning: The Sacrifice, Lord of Sacrifice, the Sacrificer, Parts of Sacrifice, Vehicle of Sacrifice
lines.note: Shloka 103 second half. First Yajna series - five sacrifice-related names.

etymology.explanation: The Sacrifice; who is the sacrifice itself
Lord of Sacrifice; master of all yajnas
The Sacrificer; who performs the eternal yajna
Parts of Sacrifice; whose limbs are the components of yajna
Vehicle of Sacrifice; who conveys offerings to devas

lines.meaning: Sustainer of Sacrifice, Performer of Sacrifice, the Sacrificial One, Enjoyer of Sacrifice, Accomplisher of Sacrifice
lines.note: Shloka 104 first half. Second Yajna series - five more sacrifice names.

etymology.explanation: Sustainer of Sacrifice; who maintains all yajnas
Performer of Sacrifice; who executes the cosmic yajna
The Sacrificial One; embodiment of yajna
Enjoyer of Sacrifice; who receives all offerings
Accomplisher of Sacrifice; who brings yajna to fruition

lines.meaning: Accomplisher of Sacrifice End, Secret of Sacrifice, Food, Eater of Food
lines.note: Shloka 104 second half. End of Yajna series; Anna (food) names.

etymology.explanation: Accomplisher of Sacrifice End; who completes all yajnas
Secret of Sacrifice; the hidden essence of yajna
Food; who is food sustaining all life
Eater of Food; who consumes all at dissolution

lines.meaning: Self-Born, Self-Manifested, the Boar (Vaikhana), Singer of Sama Veda
lines.note: Shloka 105 first half. THE 1000TH NAME (Samagayanah) - Singer of Sama Veda! Milestone completion!

etymology.explanation: Self-Born; whose source is himself alone
Self-Manifested; who manifests by his own will
The Boar; who dug up the earth (Varaha avatar)
Singer of Sama Veda; who delights in the melodious Sama chants

lines.meaning: Joy of Devaki, the Creator, Lord of Earth, Destroyer of Sins
